**Chapter 30: Discourse on Swords (Volume 10, Part 1)**

In former times, King Wen of Zhao was fond of swords. Over three thousand swordsmen thronged his gates as retainers, clashing day and night before him. Each year, a hundred perished or were wounded, yet his passion knew no satiation. After three years of this, the state declined, and the feudal lords plotted against him.

Crown Prince Kui grew anxious and offered a reward to his attendants: “Whoever can persuade the king to cease his obsession with swordsmen shall receive a thousand gold pieces.” His attendants replied, “Zhuangzi is the one for this.” The prince then sent envoys bearing a thousand gold to present to Zhuangzi.

Zhuangzi declined the gift but accompanied the envoys to see the prince. He asked, “What instruction does the prince have for me, that he bestows a thousand gold?” The prince said, “I have heard that you, Master, are enlightened and sagely. I humbly offer this gold to honor your attendants. If you refuse it, how dare I speak further?”

Zhuangzi replied, “I have heard that the prince wishes to employ me to end the king’s fondness for swords. If I persuade the king but oppose his will, or fail to please the prince, I would face execution. What use would gold be to me then? But if I succeed in persuading the king and satisfy the prince, what in Zhao could I not obtain?”

The prince said, “Indeed. My father the king sees only swordsmen.” Zhuangzi said, “Very well. I am skilled in the sword.” The prince said, “Yet the swordsmen the king favors all have unkempt hair, bristling sideburns, slouching caps, tassels of coarse silk, short-backed robes, glaring eyes, and harsh speech. The king delights in them. If you, Master, appear before him in Confucian garb, the matter will surely fail.”

Zhuangzi said, “Permit me to prepare a swordsman’s attire.” After three days, he had his sword attire ready and was presented to the prince. The prince then brought him before the king, who stood with bared blade awaiting him.

Zhuangzi entered the palace gates without haste and did not bow to the king. The king asked, “What instruction do you bring, that the prince precedes you?” Zhuangzi replied, “I have heard of your fondness for swords, so I have come to present myself as a swordsman.”

The king asked, “What can your sword do to restrain others?” Zhuangzi said, “My sword cuts down one man every ten paces, leaving no trace in its path.” The king was greatly pleased and exclaimed, “Then you are invincible under heaven!”

Zhuangzi said, “The way of the sword is to present emptiness, open the advantage, strike after the opponent moves, and arrive before him. I wish to demonstrate this.” The king said, “Rest now, Master. Return to your lodging and await my summons. I shall arrange a contest and invite you.”

The king then assembled swordsmen for seven days. Over sixty were killed or wounded, and five or six were selected. These were ordered to present their swords at the palace steps, whereupon the king summoned Zhuangzi.

The king said, “Today, let the swordsmen test their skill in earnest.” Zhuangzi replied, “I have long awaited this.” The king asked, “What length of weapon do you prefer, Master?” Zhuangzi said, “Any I am given will suffice. Yet I possess three swords, to be wielded as the king wishes. Permit me to describe them before demonstrating.”

The king said, “I wish to hear of them.” Zhuangzi said, “There is the sword of the Son of Heaven, the sword of the feudal lords, and the sword of the commoner.”

The king asked, “What is the sword of the Son of Heaven like?” Zhuangzi replied, “The sword of the Son of Heaven has its blade forged from Yanxi and Shicheng, its edge from Mount Tai of Qi, its spine from Jin and Wei, its guard from Zhou and Song, and its grip from Liang. It is bound by the Four Barbarians, wrapped in the Four Seasons, encircled by the Bohai Sea, and girded by Mount Chang.”

This sword is governed by the Five Phases, judged by punishment and virtue; opened by yin and yang, held by spring and summer, and wielded by autumn and winter. When this sword is drawn, none stand before it; when raised, none surpass it; when pressed downward, none lie beneath it; when swung, none stand beside it. Above, it parts the floating clouds; below, it severs the earth’s foundations. Once this sword is employed, the feudal lords are brought to order, and all under heaven submit. This is the sword of the Son of Heaven.”

King Wen, overwhelmed, lost himself in thought and said, “What is the sword of the feudal lords like?”

Zhuangzi replied, “The sword of the feudal lords has its blade forged from the wise and brave, its edge from the pure and resolute, its spine from the worthy and good, its guard from the loyal and sagely, and its grip from the heroic and outstanding. This sword, when drawn, likewise has none before it; when raised, none above it; when pressed downward, none beneath it; when swung, none beside it. Above, it models the round heavens, following the Three Luminaries; below, it models the square earth, following the Four Seasons. Within, it harmonizes the people’s will, bringing peace to the four directions. Once this sword is employed, it strikes like thunder, and within the four borders, none fail to submit and heed its command. This is the sword of the feudal lords.”

The king asked, “What is the sword of the commoner like?”

Zhuangzi said, “The sword of the commoner is wielded by those with unkempt hair and bristling sideburns, wearing drooping caps with loose, tangled cords, short-backed robes, glaring fiercely as they argue, clashing before one another. Above, they sever necks and throats; below, they pierce livers. This sword of the commoner differs not from fighting cocks—once their lives are spent, they serve no purpose in the affairs of state. Now, Your Majesty, possessing the position of the Son of Heaven, yet delighting in the sword of the commoner—I privately deem this unworthy of you.”

The king then led Zhuangzi by the hand and ascended the hall. The royal chef presented the meal, and the king circled it thrice. Zhuangzi said, “May Your Majesty sit composed and calm your qi. The matter of the swords has been presented in full!”

Thereupon, King Wen did not leave the palace for three months, and the swordsmen all died by their own hands where they stood.

---

Confucius wandered in the forest of black curtains and rested upon the Apricot Terrace. His disciples read aloud, while Confucius plucked the zither and sang. The melody was not yet half-finished when an old fisherman came ashore, his beard and brows snowy white, hair unbound, sleeves swaying as he walked up from the marsh. He stopped at the edge of the land, left hand resting on his knee, right hand supporting his chin, listening. When the song ended, he beckoned to Zilu and Zigong, who both stepped forward.

The stranger pointed at Confucius and asked, “Who is that man?”

Zilu replied, “A gentleman of Lu.”

The stranger asked of his lineage, and Zilu answered, “The Kong clan.”

“And what does the Kong clan govern?”

Zilu did not respond, but Zigong said, “The Kong clan cultivates loyalty and trust in their nature, practices benevolence and righteousness in their conduct, refines ritual and music, and orders human relationships. Above, they are loyal to the rulers of the age; below, they transform the common people, all to benefit the world. This is what the Kong clan governs.”

The stranger asked again, “Is he a lord with lands?”

Zigong said, “No.”

“Is he an advisor to kings and marquises?”

Zigong said, “No.”

The old man laughed and turned away, saying as he walked, “Benevolent, indeed, he is—but I fear he will not escape harm to himself. With toil of mind and strain of body, he endangers his true nature. Alas!”

“How far removed he is from the Dao!”

Zilu returned and reported to Confucius. Confucius pushed aside his zither and rose, saying, “Could he be a sage?” He then descended to seek him. Reaching the riverbank, he saw the old man leaning on his staff and drawing his boat. The old man turned, saw Confucius, and stood facing him.

Confucius retreated, bowed twice, and stepped forward. The old man asked, “What do you seek?”

Confucius replied, “Earlier, Master left with words unfinished. I, Qiu, unworthy as I am, did not grasp their meaning. I waited humbly in your wake, hoping to hear even the sound of your cough or the fall of your spittle, that I might at last receive your guidance.”

The old man exclaimed, “Ah! How earnest is your love of learning!”

Confucius bowed twice and rose, saying, “I, Qiu, have cultivated learning to this day, now sixty-nine years old, yet have never heard such profound instruction. How dare I not remain open in heart?”

The old man said, “Like attracts like, and sound answers sound—this is the principle of Heaven. I shall now set forth what I possess and expound upon what concerns you. What concerns you is human affairs. When the Son of Heaven, feudal lords, ministers, and commoners—these four ranks—each rectify themselves, governance attains its beauty. But when these four abandon their stations, no disorder is greater.

When officials fulfill their duties, and each person attends to their affairs, none overstep their bounds. Thus, when fields lie fallow and homes stand exposed, when clothing and food are insufficient, when taxes and levies are unmet, when wives and concubines are discordant, when elders and juniors lack order—these are the concerns of the common people.

When one’s abilities fall short of their office, when official duties go unmanaged, when conduct is not pure and bright, when subordinates grow idle and neglectful, when meritorious deeds go unrecognized, when ranks and emoluments are not secured—these are the worries of ministers.

When the court lacks loyal ministers, when the state is benighted and disordered, when skills are unrefined, when tribute and duties are unfulfilled, when spring and autumn audiences fall behind schedule, when one does not submit to the Son of Heaven—these are the concerns of feudal lords.

When yin and yang are not in harmony, when cold and heat arrive untimely, harming the myriad things; when feudal lords act with violence and disorder, seizing and attacking one another, ravaging the people; when ritual and music lack moderation, when resources are exhausted, when human relationships are not ordered, when clans engage in licentiousness and disorder—these are the worries of the Son of Heaven’s officials.

Now, you possess neither the authority of a lord or official above, nor the office of a minister with its duties below, yet you presume to adorn ritual and music, select and order human relationships, and transform the common people. Is this not overreaching in affairs?

Moreover, people have eight flaws, and affairs have four perils—these cannot be overlooked.

To meddle in affairs not one’s own is called *zong* (presumption).
To advance without regard is called *ning* (obsequiousness).
To speak ingratiatingly to curry favor is called *chan* (flattery).
To speak without discerning right or wrong is called *yu* (sycophancy).
To delight in speaking of others’ faults is called *chan* (slander).
To sever friendships and estrange kin is called *zei* (treachery).
To praise the wicked and deceive the good is called *te* (depravity).
To lack discernment of good and bad, to accommodate both sides, and to seize what one desires is called *xian* (perfidy).

These eight flaws externally confuse others and internally harm oneself. The noble person does not befriend such, and the enlightened ruler does not employ them.

The four perils are these:
To delight in managing great affairs, altering and changing constants, and clinging to fame and merit is called *tao* (overreaching).
To monopolize knowledge, arrogate affairs, encroach upon others, and act self-righteously is called *tan* (greed).
To see one’s faults yet not change, and to hear remonstrance yet grow more obstinate, is called *hen* (obduracy).
To approve only what aligns with oneself and to reject what differs, even if good, is called *jin* (arrogance).

These are the four perils. Only when one has shed the eight flaws and is free of the four perils can one begin to be taught.”

Confucius sighed deeply, bowed twice, and rose, saying, “I, Qiu, was twice driven from Lu, had my traces erased in Wei, was felled like a tree in Song, and was besieged between Chen and Cai. I do not know what faults I committed to incur these four slanders.”

The old man’s expression turned sorrowful as he said, “How difficult it is for you to awaken! When a man flees from his shadow and shuns his footprints, the more he lifts his feet, the more footprints he leaves; the faster he runs, the more his shadow clings. Believing himself still too slow, he exhausts his strength and dies. Yet he does not know that by resting in the shade, his shadow will vanish, and by stillness, his footprints will cease. How foolish!

You scrutinize the space between benevolence and righteousness, examine the boundaries of sameness and difference, observe the changes of movement and stillness, measure the degrees of giving and receiving, order the passions of likes and dislikes, and harmonize the moderation of joy and anger—yet you nearly escape none of this. Be diligent in cultivation, guard your true nature carefully, and return things to others, and you will have no encumbrances. Now, you do not cultivate yourself but seek from others—is this not misplaced?”

Confucius sighed deeply and said, “May I ask what is meant by *zhen* (the real)?”

The old man replied, “*Zhen* is the utmost of essence and sincerity. Without essence and sincerity, one cannot move others. Forced weeping, though sorrowful, is not mournful; forced anger, though stern, is not awe-inspiring; forced affection, though smiling, is not harmonious. True sorrow is silent yet mournful; true anger is unexpressed yet awe-inspiring; true affection is unsmiling yet harmonious. When the real resides within, the spirit moves without—this is why the real is prized.

In its application to human principles:
With parents, it is kindness and filial piety;
with rulers, it is loyalty and integrity;
in drinking, it is joy;
in mourning, it is sorrow.

Loyalty and integrity take merit as their essence;
drinking takes joy as its essence;
mourning takes sorrow as its essence;
serving parents takes comfort as its essence.

When merit is achieved, no trace of it remains;
when serving parents brings comfort, no means are sought;
when drinking brings joy, no particular vessels are chosen;
when mourning brings sorrow, no inquiry into ritual is made.

Ritual is what the common customs devise;
the real is what one receives from Heaven, naturally and unalterably.

Thus, the sage models Heaven and prizes the real, not constrained by custom. The foolish do this not. Unable to model Heaven and anxious about others, they do not know the value of the real. They drift along, swayed by custom, and thus are unworthy. Alas! You have long been immersed in human artifice and only now hear of the great Dao!”

Confucius bowed twice and rose, saying, “Today I, Qiu, have met you as if by Heaven’s favor.”

The master did not disdain to liken himself to a servant and personally instruct him. I venture to ask where you dwell, that I may follow and receive your teaching to complete my study of the great Dao.”

The master said, “I have heard that one may accompany those who are fit to journey with, but as for the subtle Dao, those unfit to journey with cannot comprehend it. Be cautious not to share it with them, lest you bring harm upon yourself. Strive on! I leave you now, I leave you now!” With that, he poled his boat away, gliding along the reeds.

Yan Yuan turned the chariot around, while Zilu handed the reins. Confucius did not look back, waiting until the water’s ripples stilled and the sound of the oar vanished before daring to board. Zilu stepped beside the chariot and asked, “I have long served you, yet never have I seen you meet another with such reverence. Even the lords of ten thousand chariots or the rulers of a thousand, when they meet you, do not fail to observe proper courtesy, yet you still maintain a dignified bearing. Now this old fisherman, leaning on his oar and standing upright, and you bowed at the waist like a chime stone, responding with words and bows—was this not excessive? Your disciples all find it strange. How could this fisherman deserve such treatment?”

Confucius leaned on the crossbar and sighed, saying, “How deeply entrenched your difficulty in transformation is! Though you have been steeped in ritual and propriety for some time, your rustic and coarse heart remains unchanged to this day. Come closer, let me tell you: to fail to show respect when meeting an elder is impropriety; to fail to honor the worthy is a lack of benevolence. If he were not a perfected person, he could not humble himself before others. Without perfecting humility, one cannot attain the real, and thus one’s person suffers lasting harm. Alas! There is no greater misfortune for a person than a lack of benevolence, and you alone cling to it. Moreover, the Dao is the path by which all things proceed. Those who lose it die; those who attain it live. Acting against it brings failure; following it brings success. Therefore, wherever the Dao resides, the sage honors it. This old fisherman may be said to possess it—how could I dare not show respect?”

---

When Liezi of Lie Yukou journeyed to Qi, he turned back midway and encountered Bohun Maoren. Bohun Maoren asked, “Why have you returned?”

Liezi said, “I was alarmed.”

“By what?”

“I dined at ten inns, and at five of them, the broth was served before the rice.”

Bohun Maoren said, “If that is so, why were you alarmed?”

Liezi replied, “Though my inner sincerity was not yet dissolved, my outward demeanor shone with self-importance, thereby unsettling others’ hearts and causing them to treat the honored and the aged lightly, stirring up the very troubles they seek to avoid. Now, the broth-sellers merely trade in food and drink, with no great profit to spare. Their influence is slight, their power light, yet even so, they acted thus—how much more so the lords of ten thousand chariots? Their bodies are wearied by the state, their knowledge exhausted by affairs. They would entrust me with tasks and demand results from me. That is why I was alarmed.”

Bohun Maoren said, “Excellent observation!”

"Now abide thus, and others will come to preserve you!"

Before long, Liezi returned to find the space outside the door filled with shoes. Bohun Maoren stood facing north, his staff planted firmly beneath his chin. After a time, he spoke not a word and departed. The attendant informed Liezi, who rushed out barefoot, shoes in hand, and caught up at the gate:

"Master, since you have come, will you not dispense your remedy?"

Bohun Maoren replied, "It is done. I had already told you: others will come to preserve you—and indeed, they have preserved you! You may make others preserve you, yet you cannot make them cease preserving you—why then do you seek to stir their admiration with such extraordinary displays? If you must provoke a response, let it arise from your root nature, not from empty gestures. Those who wander with you offer no true counsel. Their petty words are all poison to men. None awaken, none perceive—how can they discern one another? The cunning toil, the wise fret, the capable seek nothing. Sated, they roam at ease, drifting like untethered boats—empty, they wander freely!"

Zheng’s Huan sighed and groaned upon the lands of Qiu.

"Within three years, Huan of Zheng became a Confucian. As a river moistens nine *li* and its blessings extend to three clans, his younger brother became a Mohist. The Confucians and Mohists debated, and their father sided with Mo Di. After ten years, Huan took his own life. In a dream, his father addressed him: 'It was I who made your son a Mohist—why did you never examine his true nature? Had he already become the fruit of the autumn cypress?'

The Creator’s retribution upon men does not punish the man himself but the Heaven within him—thus it was for Huan. When a man deems himself possessed of something that sets him apart from others, thereby dishonoring his kin, even those who draw water from the same well will come to blows. Thus it is said: all in this age are Huan. From this, those with virtue do so without awareness—how much more so those who embody the Dao!

In ancient times, this was called 'the punishment of fleeing from Heaven.' The sage finds peace in what is inherently peaceful and does not seek peace in what is inherently restless; the multitude seeks peace in what is inherently restless and finds no peace in what is inherently peaceful."

Zhuangzi said: "To know the Dao is easy; to refrain from speaking of it is difficult. To know and not speak—this is the way to Heaven. To know and speak—this is the way of man. The ancients followed Heaven and not man."

Zhu Pingman studied dragon-slaying under Zhi Liyi, exhausting a thousand gold from his family. After three years, his skill was perfected—yet there was no use for his craft.

The sage takes what must not be as what must not be, and so has no weapons. The multitude takes what must not be as what must be, and so has many weapons. Yielding to weapons, their actions become demands. Where weapons go, ruin follows.

The petty man’s knowledge clings to bribes and trivial documents, wasting his spirit on the shallow and narrow, yet seeks to encompass the Dao and all things, to embody the Great Unity and the formless. Such a one is lost amid the cosmos, his form burdened, unaware of the Great Beginning.

The perfected person returns his spirit to the beginningless, merging with the realm of Nothing Whatever. Like water flowing without form, it disperses into the Great Purity.

Alas! You take your knowledge to be as fine as a hair’s tip, yet do not know the Great Peace!

There was a man of Song named Cao Shang, sent by the King of Song as an envoy to Qin. On his journey, he obtained several carriages. The King of Qin was pleased with him and added a hundred more carriages. Returning to Song, he saw Zhuangzi and said: “To dwell in a cramped alley, impoverished and weaving sandals, with a withered neck and sallow face—this is what I was poor at. But to awaken a ruler of ten thousand chariots and follow with a hundred carriages—this is what I excel at.”

Zhuangzi replied: “When the King of Qin was ill, he summoned physicians. Those who lanced boils and drained abscesses received one carriage; those who licked his hemorrhoids received five carriages. The baser the treatment, the more carriages they received. Did you, perhaps, treat his ailments? Why else would you have received so many carriages?”

"Be gone!" Duke Ai of Lu asked Yan He, saying: "I take Zhongni as the pillar of the state—will the nation then recover?" Yan He replied: "Kong Qiu is perilous indeed! He adorns himself with feathers and paints, engages in florid speech, takes the branch for the root, and suppresses his nature to gaze upon the people. He knows not what is untrustworthy, yet receives it in his heart as steward. How could such a one be fit to govern the people? Is he fit for you? Or fit for me? To err thus is permissible! Now, to cause the people to depart from true learning and embrace falsity—this is no way to govern them. To consider posterity thus is unwise. Cease this course, for governance will be difficult!"

What is bestowed upon others yet not forgotten is not the Heavenly distribution. Merchants are held in contempt; even when ranked among them by office, the spiritually attuned hold them in contempt. External punishments are meted out by metal and wood; internal punishments arise from movement and transgression. When petty men incur external punishments, metal and wood interrogate them; when they incur internal punishments, yin and yang consume them. Only the truly capable escape both inner and outer punishments.

Confucius said: "The human heart is more treacherous than mountains and rivers, harder to know than Heaven. Heaven at least has its seasons—spring, autumn, winter, summer—and its fixed times of dawn and dusk. But man conceals his nature beneath a thick façade. Thus, some appear sincere yet are insatiable; some seem long-suffering yet are unworthy; some are compliant yet perverse; some are resolute yet lax; some are gentle yet fierce. Those who rush to righteousness do so as if parched; those who flee it do so as if scorched. Therefore, the noble man sends them far to observe their loyalty, keeps them near to observe their reverence, burdens them to observe their ability, questions them suddenly to observe their knowledge, sets urgent deadlines to observe their trustworthiness, entrusts them with wealth to observe their benevolence, warns them of danger to observe their integrity, intoxicates them with wine to observe their composure, and mingles them with others to observe their demeanor. When these nine tests are complete, the unworthy are revealed."

Zheng Kaofu, upon his first appointment, bent low; upon his second, stooped; upon his third, bowed deeply, creeping along the wall—who would dare transgress! Yet there are those who, upon their first appointment, strut like Lü Ju; upon their second, dance atop their carriage; upon their third, address elders by name. Who could align with Tang or Xu? No calamity is greater than virtue with intent, and intent with eyelashes. Once intent has eyelashes, it turns inward; turning inward, it fails.

There are five inauspicious virtues, with "central virtue" foremost. What is central virtue? It is one who, while esteeming himself, reviles what he does not possess. There are eight extremes of poverty and three certainties of success; the body has six repositories. Beauty, whiskers, height, stature, strength, comeliness, courage, and boldness—those who surpass others in all eight rely on these. Following customs, reclining, or cowering in fear when inferior to others—these three lead to success. Wisdom and intelligence that reach outward breed resentment; bold action invites many grudges; benevolence and righteousness bring many demands. Those who penetrate to the truth of success are puppets; those who penetrate to knowledge are diminished. Those who grasp the great mandate follow; those who grasp the small mandate encounter it.

A man who had an audience with the King of Song was granted ten carriages. With these ten carriages, he arrogantly boasted to Zhuangzi. Zhuangzi said: "By the river there was a poor family who wove rushes to eat. Their son dived into the depths and obtained a pearl worth a thousand gold pieces. His father said to him: 'Bring a stone to pound it! A pearl of a thousand gold pieces must lie in the ninefold abyss beneath the chin of a black dragon. That you could obtain it means you must have encountered its sleep. Had the black dragon awakened, what trace of you would remain?' Now, the depths of the state of Song are not merely a ninefold abyss; the ferocity of the King of Song is not merely that of a black dragon. That you could obtain these carriages means you must have encountered his sleep. Had the King of Song awakened, you would be reduced to mincemeat."

Someone sought to engage Zhuangzi’s services, and Zhuangzi replied to the envoy: "Have you seen the sacrificial ox? Clothed in embroidered brocade, fed on fine hay and grain—yet when it is led into the great temple, would it still wish to be a lonely calf?"

As Zhuangzi neared death, his disciples wished to give him a lavish burial. Zhuangzi said: "I take heaven and earth as my inner and outer coffin, the sun and moon as my paired jades, the stars as my pearls and beads, and the ten thousand things as my funeral gifts. Are not my burial furnishings complete? What could be added to them?" His disciples said: "We fear the crows and kites will devour you." Zhuangzi replied: "Above, I would be eaten by crows and kites; below, by ants and mole crickets. To snatch from one to give to the other—how partial is that!"

To level with what is not level is to make leveling unlevel; to verify with what is not verifiable is to make verification unverifiable. The enlightened are but servants of it; the spiritually attuned are its witnesses. That the enlightened cannot surpass the spiritually attuned has long been so—yet fools rely on what they see to impose upon others. Their achievements are external; is this not lamentable?

**Chapter Thirty-Three: "The World"**

Those in the world who cultivate methods of governance are many, each believing their own way cannot be surpassed. What, then, was the Dao/Way of the ancients? It was said: "Nowhere is it not present." It was asked: "How does the spirit descend? How does clarity emerge?" It was answered: "The sage has a source of arising; the king has a source of accomplishment—both are one."

Not departing from the origin is called the Heavenly Person; not departing from the essence is called the Spirit Person; not departing from the real is called the Perfected Person. Taking heaven as the origin, virtue/power as the root, and the Dao/Way as the gate, foretelling change and transformation—this is called the sage. Taking benevolence as kindness, righteousness as principle, ritual as conduct, and music as harmony, exuding gentle compassion—this is called the gentleman. Taking law as distinction, names as markers, evidence as proof, and investigation as decision, counting one, two, three, four as their measure, officials rank one another by this, taking affairs as the norm, clothing and food as the priority, multiplying and storing, caring for the old, weak, orphaned, and widowed—this is the governance of the people.

The ancients were complete! They matched the spirit luminaries, harmonized with heaven and earth, nurtured the myriad things, brought harmony to the world, and extended their blessings to the hundred clans. Illuminating the root and the numbers, connecting to the branches and the measures, penetrating the six directions and opening the four gates, whether small or great, refined or coarse, their movement was nowhere absent.

What is clear and lies in numbers and measures—old laws and transmitted histories still preserve much of it. What lies in the *Book of Songs*, *Book of Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music*—scholars of Zou and Lu, and the gentry, can often clarify it. The *Songs* convey the will; the *Documents* convey affairs; the *Rites* convey conduct; the *Music* conveys harmony; the *Changes* convey yin and yang; the *Spring and Autumn Annals* convey names and duties. These methods spread throughout the world and within the central states, and the hundred schools of thought occasionally praise and expound them.

When the world was in great disorder, the worthy and sagely were obscured, and the Dao/Way and virtue/power were not unified. People in the world each grasped one insight and took pride in it. Like the ears and eyes, each has its clarity but cannot communicate with the other. Like the hundred schools and their arts, each has its strengths and occasional uses. Yet they are not comprehensive or all-encompassing—they are partial scholars.

Judging the beauty of heaven and earth, analyzing the principles of the ten thousand things, examining the wholeness of the ancients—few can fully grasp the beauty of heaven and earth or match the bearing of the spirit. Thus, the Dao/Way of inner sageliness and outer kingship has grown dim and unmanifest, pent-up and unexpressed. People in the world each follow their desires to create their own methods. How lamentable! The hundred schools have gone forth and not returned—they will surely not converge.

Later scholars, unfortunately, do not see the purity of heaven and earth or the great form of the ancients. The Dao/Way is about to be torn apart by the world. Not extravagant toward later generations, not wasteful toward the ten thousand things, not dazzled by numbers and measures, using the inked cord to correct themselves and prepare for the world’s emergencies—there are those in whom the Dao/Way resides.

Mo Di and Qin Guli heard of this wind and delighted in it. They overdid it greatly, yet considered it the greatest compliance. They composed *Against Music* and called it *Moderation in Use*. They did not sing in life and wore no mourning in death. Mozi advocated universal love and mutual benefit while opposing strife; his Dao/Way did not involve anger. He was also fond of learning and broad in knowledge, yet did not align with the former kings, instead condemning the rites and music of antiquity.

The Yellow Emperor had *Xianchi*; Yao had *Great Chapter*; Shun had *Great Shao*; Yu had *Great Xia*; Tang had *Great Hu*; King Wen had the music of the *Biyong*; King Wu and the Duke of Zhou composed *Wu*. In the mourning rites of antiquity, the noble and base had their proper forms, the high and low their ranks. The Son of Heaven had seven layers of inner and outer coffins; the feudal lords, five; the great officers, three; and the scholars, two. Yet Mozi alone advocated no singing in life and no mourning in death, using a paulownia coffin three inches thick without an outer coffin as the model. Teaching others this, he did not seem to love them; practicing it himself, he certainly did not love himself. Though Mozi’s Dao/Way has not yet failed, singing yet not singing, weeping yet not weeping, joy yet not joy—is this truly fitting? His life was toilsome, his death meager, his Dao/Way harsh. He made people anxious, made people sorrowful—his conduct was difficult to follow. I fear he will not be taken as a sage but will instead turn the world’s heart away. The world cannot endure it. Though Mozi alone could bear it, what can he do about the world? Separated from the world, he is far from the kingly way!

Mozi proclaimed: "In ancient times, Yu controlled the floodwaters, dredged the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers to connect the four barbarians and the nine provinces. The great rivers numbered three hundred, the tributaries three thousand, and the smaller streams were innumerable. Yu personally wielded the spade and basket to dredge the world’s rivers..."

His calves bore no flesh, his shins no hair—soaked by torrential rains, combed by fierce winds, he settled the myriad states. Yu was a great sage, yet his body toiled for the world to such an extent.

Thus later Mohists, many clad in coarse wool and hemp, bound their feet in sandals, laboring day and night without rest, taking self-affliction as the utmost virtue. They declared: "Without this, one does not follow Yu’s Dao/Way and is unworthy to be called a Mohist." The disciples of Xiangli Qin, the followers of Wu Hou, and the southern Mohists such as Huo, Yi Chi, and Deng Lingzi—all recited the *Mo Jing*, yet their interpretations diverged, each calling the others "deviant Mohists." They disparaged one another with debates on "hard and white" and "same and different," responded with arguments of "odd and even" and "non-correspondence," and revered the *juzi* as a sage. All wished to be his embodiment, hoping to succeed him, yet to this day the matter remains unresolved. Mo Di and Qin Guli’s intent was sound, but their conduct was misguided. They would compel later Mohists to advance only by emulating Yu’s self-mortification—calves without flesh, shins without hair. This is the height of disorder, the nadir of governance.

Nevertheless, Mozi was truly the world’s finest. One could seek his like in vain; though withered and gaunt, he never abandoned his cause. What a man of talent! Unburdened by convention, unadorned by externals, uncompromising with others, unhostile to the multitude, he longed for the world’s peace to preserve the people’s lives. His own sustenance sufficed once fulfilled, and with this he purified his heart.

Among the ancient arts of the Dao/Way, some resided in this. Song Xing and Yin Wen, hearing of his spirit, delighted in it. They crafted flower-shaped caps to mark themselves, engaging with all things by first dispelling prejudice. They spoke of the heart’s capacity, calling it "the heart’s conduct," seeking harmony through gentleness and inwardness. They wished to establish this as their guiding principle. Unashamed by insult, they rescued people from strife, forbade aggression, and halted warfare to save the world from conflict. With this, they traversed the world, persuading rulers above and instructing the people below. Though the world did not accept them, they persisted stubbornly, refusing to desist. Thus it is said: they were wearying to both high and low, yet forced themselves upon them.

Yet their conduct was excessive, their self-restraint too meager. They declared: "Five pints of rice suffice. Though the master may not be full, the disciples, though hungry, do not forget the world." Day and night they labored without rest, saying: "We must surely save lives! How proud we are among those who rescue the world!" They held: "The noble person is not overly scrupulous, nor lends himself to things. What benefits not the world is better left unclarified."

They took the prohibition of warfare as their external concern and the moderation of desires as their internal one. In matters great and small, refined and coarse, their conduct extended only so far. Impartial yet not partisan, yielding yet without bias, resolute yet without fixed views, they followed things without duality, unburdened by deliberation, unguided by cunning. Things were not chosen; they moved with them as one. Among the ancient arts of the Dao/Way, some resided in this.

Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao, hearing of this spirit, delighted in it. They took the equalization of the myriad things as their starting point, saying: "Heaven can cover but not bear them; earth can bear but not cover them; the great Dao/Way can encompass but not distinguish them." Knowing all things have what they can and cannot do, they declared: "Selection is not universal; teaching does not reach all; only the Dao/Way leaves nothing out."

Thus Shen Dao abandoned knowledge and self, following only what could not be avoided. He flowed with things, taking this as the principle of the Dao/Way. He said: "To know yet appear not to know is to verge on harming knowledge." Unconstrained and unburdened, he mocked the world’s esteem for worthies; unshackled and unprincipled, he rejected the world’s great sages. Leveling and severing, he turned with things, discarding right and wrong to merely avoid harm. Unbound by knowledge or foresight, without precedence or delay, he stood alone. Pushed, he moved; pulled, he went—like a whirling gale, a spinning feather, a grinding stone’s groove. Whole yet without fault, in motion or still without error, he never incurred blame. Why? Things without knowledge have no peril of self-assertion; their use imposes no burden, their movement and stillness never depart from principle, so they live without praise. Thus it is said: "Attain the state of unknowing things; do not employ worthies or sages. An uncarved block does not lose the Dao/Way."

The heroic mocked them, saying: "Shen Dao’s Dao/Way is not the conduct of the living but the principle of the dead—how strange!" Tian Pian was the same, studying under Peng Meng and receiving his unorthodox teaching. Peng Meng’s master said: "The ancient Daoists reached the point of neither affirming nor denying. Their spirit was vast and indistinct—how could one speak of it?" They constantly opposed others, avoiding observation yet not escaping judgment. What they called the Dao/Way was not the Dao/Way, and their so-called rightness was not free from error. Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao did not understand the Dao/Way. Nevertheless, they roughly grasped something of it.

Taking the root as refined, things as coarse, accumulation as insufficiency, they dwelled in serene solitude with the spiritually luminous. Among the ancient arts of the Dao/Way, some resided in this. Guan Yin and Lao Dan, hearing of this spirit, delighted in it. They built upon the constant of "non-being and being," centered it on the Great One, took gentleness, weakness, and humility as their outward expression, and emptiness that does not destroy the myriad things as their substance.

Guan Yin said: "Abide in nothing, and things will manifest themselves." His movement was like water, his stillness like a mirror, his response like an echo. Vague as if vanished, silent as if pure. Those who harmonized with him were at peace; those who grasped him lost. He never preceded others but always followed.

Lao Dan said: "Know the masculine, yet guard the feminine, and be a ravine to the world. Know the white, yet guard the disgraced, and be a valley to the world."

All men seek to be first, yet he alone takes the last place, saying: "I bear the world’s filth." All men seek fullness, yet he alone remains empty, holding nothing in store—thus he has abundance, towering and inexhaustible. In his conduct, he moves slowly without waste, does nothing yet mocks cleverness. All men seek fortune, yet he alone bends to preserve wholeness, saying: "Let me but escape blame." He takes depth as his root, restraint as his guiding principle, and declares: "What is hard will shatter; what is sharp will dull." Ever tolerant toward things, never carving away at others—this may be called perfection. Ah, Guan Yin and Lao Dan! They were the vast and true men of old!

Vague and formless, changing without constancy—are they dead or alive? Do they stand with heaven and earth, journey with the gods? Dim and obscure, where do they go? Where do they turn? All things are gathered in, yet none can claim them as their home. Such was the Dao/Way of the ancients.

Zhuang Zhou heard of this spirit and delighted in it. With absurd and wandering words, wild and boundless speech, endless and unbounded phrases, he gave free rein to his whims, never showing partiality. He took the world as too sunk in turbidity for solemn discourse, so he used careless words to ramble, weighty words as truth, and parables to broaden meaning. Alone he roamed with the spirit of heaven and earth, never condescending to things, never entangled in right and wrong, living among the common world. Though his writings were strange and wondrous, they flowed without harm. Though his words were uneven, their strangeness was worth beholding. His fullness could not be exhausted: above, he wandered with the Creator; below, he befriended those beyond death and without end. In his grasp of the root, he was vast and open, deep and unconstrained; in his reverence for the source, he was richly attuned and lofty. Yet in responding to change and dissolving things, his principles never ran dry, his coming never ceased. Dim and obscure—who can fathom him?

Hui Shi was a man of many methods. His writings filled five carts, yet his Dao/Way was contradictory and his words often missed the mark. In his "Survey of Things," he said: "What is utterly great has no outside—call it the Great One. What is utterly small has no inside—call it the Small One. What has no thickness cannot be accumulated, yet it spans a thousand miles. Heaven is as low as earth; mountains are level with marshes. The sun is both at its zenith and setting; things are born and die at once. Great sameness differs from small sameness—this is called 'small sameness and difference.' All things are entirely the same and entirely different—this is called 'great sameness and difference.' The south is both boundless and bounded. Today I go to Yue, yet I arrived yesterday. Linked rings can be unlinked. I know the world’s center—it lies north of Yan and south of Yue. Embrace all things, for heaven and earth are one."

Hui Shi took this as his great insight, surveying the world to enlighten debaters. The debaters of the world rejoiced in it. Eggs have feathers; a chicken has three feet; the world can be possessed; a dog can become a sheep; a frog has a tail; fire is not hot; a mountain has a mouth; a wheel does not touch the ground; eyes do not see; a finger does not reach, yet reaching never ceases; a tortoise is longer than a snake; a square is not made with a ruler, nor a circle with a compass; a chisel does not fit its handle; a flying bird’s shadow never moves; an arrow’s flight is both motionless and moving; a white dog is black; a lone colt never had a mother; take half of a one-foot stick each day, and it will never be exhausted after ten thousand generations.

Such were the exchanges with which Hui Shi matched wits, never at a loss. Huan Tuan and Gongsun Long, with their band of debaters, adorned men’s minds and altered their intentions. They could win in argument but not convince the heart—such is the trap of debaters. Hui Shi daily used his knowledge to contend with others, creating monstrosities in debate. This was his foundation. Yet in his verbal sparring, he deemed himself the worthiest, saying: "Is not heaven and earth grand? Yet Hui Shi stands mighty, though without method."

In the south there was an eccentric named Huang Liao who asked why heaven and earth do not collapse or sink, and the causes of wind, rain, and thunder. Hui Shi did not decline to answer, nor did he ponder before responding. He discoursed on all things without pause, yet still felt his words were few and added more strangeness. He took contrariness as truth and sought fame in victory—thus he never fit in with others. Weak in virtue yet strong in things, his path was narrow. Viewed by the Dao/Way of heaven and earth, Hui Shi’s efforts were like the labor of a single mosquito or gnat—what use were they to things? To be content with one thing would have been better; to value the Dao/Way would have been near perfection. Yet Hui Shi could not find peace in this. He scattered himself among the ten thousand things without surfeit, ending as a master of debate.

Alas! Hui Shi’s talent was vast but unfulfilled. Chasing the ten thousand things without return—he was like one who exhausts sound to make an echo, or races with his shadow. How sad!

chunks.original_text: 庄子（南华经） 卷一上第一逍遥游 北冥有鱼，其名为鲲。 鲲之大，不知其几千里也。 化而为鸟，其名为鹏。 鹏之背，不知其几千里也； 怒而飞，其翼若垂天之云。 是鸟也，海运则将徙于南冥。 南冥者，天池也。 齐谐者，志怪者也。 谐之言曰：「鹏之徙于南冥也，水击三千里，抟扶摇而上者九万里，去以六月息者也。 」野马也，尘埃也，生物之以息相吹也。 天之苍苍，其正色邪？ 其远而无所至极邪？ 其视下也，亦若是则已矣。 且夫水之积也不厚，则其负大舟也无力。 覆杯水于坳堂之上，则芥为之舟； 置杯焉则胶，水浅而舟大也。 风之积也不厚，则其负大翼也无力。 故九万里，则风斯在下矣，而后乃今掊风； 背负青天而莫之夭阏者，而后乃今将图南。 蜩与学鸠笑之曰：「我决起而飞，枪榆枋而止，时则不至而控于地而已矣，奚以这九万里而南为？ 」适莽苍者，三餐而反，腹犹果然； 适百里者，宿舂粮；
chunks.translated_text:
In the first chapter of the first scroll of *Zhuangzi* (*The Scripture of Southern Florescence*), "Free and Easy Wandering":

In the Northern Darkness there is a fish, and its name is Kun. The size of the Kun—no one knows how many thousand *li* it spans. It transforms into a bird, and its name is Peng. The back of the Peng—no one knows how many thousand *li* it spans. When it rouses itself and takes flight, its wings are like clouds draped across the sky. This bird, when the seas surge, will journey to the Southern Darkness. The Southern Darkness is the Celestial Pond.

*Qi Xie* is a record of marvels. Its words say: "When the Peng journeys to the Southern Darkness, the waters churn for three thousand *li*. It mounts the whirlwind and ascends ninety thousand *li*, borne on the winds of a six-month exhalation." The wild galloping of vapors, the drifting of dust motes—these are living things blown about by each other’s breath.

Is the deep blue of the sky its true color? Or is it because it stretches so far that nothing marks its end? When the Peng looks down, it sees only the same.

Moreover, if water does not accumulate to sufficient depth, it lacks the strength to bear a great vessel. Pour a cup of water into a hollow in the floor, and a mustard seed becomes a boat; set a cup there, and it sticks fast—too shallow the water, too great the vessel. If wind does not accumulate to sufficient depth, it lacks the strength to bear great wings. Thus, at ninety thousand *li*, the wind lies beneath it, and only then can it ride the gale. With the azure sky at its back and nothing to obstruct its path, only then does it set its course for the south.

The cicada and the fledgling dove laugh at it, saying: "We burst forth and fly, darting to the elm or sandalwood, and when we cannot reach, we simply alight upon the ground—what need have we to ascend ninety thousand *li* and journey south?"

One who travels to the near wilds brings three meals and returns with belly still full. One who travels a hundred *li* must pound grain for the night’s provisions.

chunks.translated_text:
One who travels a thousand *li* must gather provisions for three months. What do these two creatures know? Lesser knowledge does not reach greater knowledge; short years do not reach long years. How do we know this is so? The morning mushroom knows not dawn nor dusk; the cicada knows not spring nor autumn—these are short years. South of Chu lies the *Mingling* tree, for which five hundred years make a spring, five hundred years an autumn. In high antiquity there was the great *Chun* tree, for which eight thousand years make a spring, eight thousand years an autumn—these are long years. Yet Pengzu alone is famed for his longevity; for common folk to compare themselves to him—is this not lamentable?

This is what Tang asked Ji about. In the dark northern sea of the barren lands, there is a heavenly pool. There is a fish there, several thousand *li* in breadth, whose length none knows—its name is Kun. There is a bird there, its name Peng, its back like Mount Tai, its wings like clouds hanging from the sky. It wheels upon the whirlwind, rising ninety thousand *li*, piercing the clouds, bearing the azure sky on its back, then sets its course south, bound for the southern darkness.

The marsh pipit laughs at it, saying: "Where does it think it’s going? I leap and soar, rising no more than a few fathoms before descending, wheeling among the mugwort and wormwood—this is the perfection of flight! Where does it think it’s going?" This is the distinction between small and great.

Thus, those whose knowledge suffices for one office, whose conduct is matched in one village, whose virtue pleases one lord, or whose merit is proven in one state—such men regard themselves as the marsh pipit does. Yet Song Rongzi would still laugh at them. When the whole world praises him, he is not spurred on; when the whole world blames him, he is not disheartened. He has settled the division between inner and outer, discerned the boundary between honor and disgrace—this is all. In his dealings with the world, he is not eager. Even so, he has yet to plant his roots.

Liezi rides the wind and travels, lightly and well, returning after fifteen days. In his pursuit of fortune, he is not eager. Though he avoids walking, he still depends on something. But if one were to ride the constancy of Heaven and Earth, harness the transformations of the six qi, and wander through the boundless—what would he depend on? Thus it is said: the Perfect Man has no self, the Spirit Man has no merit, the Sage has no name.

Yao offered the world to Xu You, saying: "When the sun and moon have risen, yet the torch still burns—is it not difficult for its light to be seen? When the rain has fallen, yet one still waters the fields—is this not labor in vain? You stand, and the world is ordered; yet I still occupy the throne—I see myself as lacking. Take the world."

Xu You replied: "You govern the world, and the world is already well-governed. Yet I would still replace you—would I do so for a name? A name is but the guest of reality; would I be a guest?"

chunks.translated_text:
The wren nests in the deep forest, yet needs no more than a single branch; the mole drinks from the river, yet takes no more than fills its belly. Go home, my lord—I have no use for the world!

Though the cook neglects his kitchen, the invocator at the altar would not leap over the wine vessels and sacrificial stands to take his place.

Jian Wu asked Lian Shu: "I heard words from Jie Yu that were vast but without measure, sweeping onward without return. I was startled and terrified by them—they were as boundless as the Milky Way, wildly divergent, far from human sensibilities."

Lian Shu said: "What did he say?"

Jian Wu replied: "On distant Mount Gushe, a spirit-man dwells. His skin is like ice and snow, his grace like a maiden’s. He eats no five grains, but drinks the wind and sips the dew. He rides the clouds and qi, drives dragons, and wanders beyond the four seas. His spirit is so concentrated that he keeps things free from blight and ensures the harvest ripens. Yet I deem this madness and do not believe it."

Lian Shu said: "Indeed. The blind cannot partake in the sight of patterns, nor the deaf in the sound of bells and drums. Is it only the body that can be deaf and blind? The understanding, too, may suffer the same."

Such words of his are but the prattling of a child. That man, that power of his—it would sweep across the ten thousand things, uniting them as one, while the world yearns for order. Who would wear themselves out taking the world as their task!

That man—nothing harms him. Though the great floods rise to the heavens, he does not drown; though great drought melts metal and stone, scorches earth and mountains, he does not burn. From his dust and chaff, one could mold a Yao or Shun—who would trouble themselves with mere things!

The men of Song carried ceremonial caps to Yue, yet the people of Yue cut their hair short and tattoo their bodies, having no use for them. Yao governed the people of the world and brought order to the lands within the seas. Yet when he went to see the Four Masters on distant Mount Gushe, north of the Fen River, he was so profoundly moved that he forgot his rule over the world.

Hui Zi said to Zhuangzi: "The King of Wei gave me seeds of a great gourd. I planted them, and they grew to bear fruit of five *shi*. When I used it to hold water, its strength was not enough to support itself. When I split it to make a ladle, its size was so vast it could hold nothing. It was not that it was not resoundingly large—I deemed it useless and smashed it."

Zhuangzi said: "You are indeed clumsy in putting great things to use. There was a man of Song skilled in making an ointment that prevented chapped hands. For generations, his family had made their living by washing silk floss. A traveler heard of this and offered to buy the formula for a hundred gold pieces. The family gathered and deliberated: 'For generations, we have washed silk floss and earned no more than a few gold pieces. Now, in a single morning, we can sell this skill for a hundred gold pieces—let us give it to him.'

The traveler obtained it and used it to persuade the King of Wu. When Yue raised a rebellion, the King of Wu sent him to lead the troops. In the winter, they fought a naval battle with Yue, and he utterly defeated the Yue forces, winning a fiefdom as his reward. The ability to prevent chapped hands was the same, yet one man gained a fiefdom, while another could not escape washing silk floss—such is the difference in how it was used.

Now you have a gourd of five *shi*—why not consider making it into a great float and drifting upon the rivers and lakes, instead of fretting that it is too large to hold anything? Truly, your mind is still as tangled as a clump of weeds!"

Hui Shi said to Zhuangzi: "I have a great tree, which people call the *chu*. Its massive trunk is gnarled and does not meet the carpenter’s line, its slender branches are twisted and do not conform to compass or square. Planted by the roadside, no craftsman even glances at it. Now, your words are grand but of no use—just as the multitude discards them."

Zhuangzi replied: "Have you alone never seen the wildcat or weasel? Crouching low to lie in wait, it pounces on its prey; leaping east and west, it spares neither high nor low. Are all these but servants and handmaids? Are servants and handmaids insufficient to govern one another? Do they take turns being lord and subject? Or is there a true lord that abides? Whether one seeks and attains its truth or fails to do so, it neither adds to nor detracts from its reality. Once receiving this completed form, one does not perish until its end. Engaging with things, they grind and wear against one another—one’s conduct races to its end like a galloping steed, yet none can halt it. Is this not lamentable? A lifetime spent toiling without seeing success, wearily exhausted yet unaware of one’s destination—how can this not be sorrowful? People call it "not dying," but what benefit is there? The body transforms, and the heart follows suit—can this not be called great sorrow? Is human life inherently so deluded? Am I alone in my confusion, or are there others who are not?

Those who follow their settled minds as teachers—who is without a teacher? Why must one know the succession of ages to have a mind that grasps itself? Even fools possess this! When the mind is formed and there is right and wrong, it is like arriving in Yue today yet having reached it yesterday. Thus, one takes what does not exist to be existent. Taking what does not exist to be existent, even the divine Yu would be at a loss—what can I alone do?

Words are not the wind’s breath; speakers have their say. Yet what they say remains unsettled. Is there truly speech? Or has there never been speech? If one deems it distinct from the chirping of fledglings, is there still distinction? Or is there none? Where does the Dao hide that it has truth and falsehood? Where does speech hide that it has right and wrong? Where does the Dao go that it ceases to exist? Where does speech abide that it cannot be affirmed? The Dao is obscured by petty achievements; speech is obscured by florid ornamentation. Hence, there are the Confucians’ and Mohists’ disputes over right and wrong, each affirming what the other denies and denying what the other affirms. To affirm what they deny and deny what they affirm, nothing surpasses clarity.

Nothing exists that is not "that"; nothing exists that is not "this." From "that," one does not see; from self-knowledge, one knows. Thus it is said: "That emerges from this, and this likewise depends on that." This is the theory of simultaneous arising. Yet even as things arise, they die; as they die, they arise. Even as they are affirmed, they are denied; as they are denied, they are affirmed. Affirming this and denying that, denying this and affirming that—therefore, the sage does not proceed thus but illuminates all by the light of Heaven. This, too, is "that," and "that," too, is "this." "That" has its right and wrong, and "this" has its right and wrong. Is there truly a "that" and a "this"? Or is there truly neither "that" nor "this"? Where "that" and "this" find no counterpart, this is called the pivot of the Dao. Once the pivot is grasped at the center of the circle, it responds endlessly. "This" is endless, and "not-this" is likewise endless. Thus, it is said: nothing surpasses clarity.

To use a finger to illustrate that a finger is not a finger is not as good as using a non-finger to illustrate that a finger is not a finger. To use a horse to illustrate that a horse is not a horse is not as good as using a non-horse to illustrate that a horse is not a horse. Heaven and Earth are one finger; the myriad things are one horse.

What can be affirmed is affirmed; what cannot be affirmed cannot be affirmed. The Dao is realized through action; things are so called by convention. Why are they so? They are so because they are so. Why are they not so? They are not so because they are not so. Things inherently have what they affirm and what they accept. Nothing is not so; nothing is unacceptable. Therefore, whether one takes a stalk or a pillar, a leper or Xi Shi, the grotesque, the strange, the deceptive, and the bizarre—the Dao unites them all as one. In their division, they are completed; in their completion, they are destroyed. All things are neither completed nor destroyed, but return to unity.

Only the enlightened know this unity and, for this reason, do not employ it but lodge it in the ordinary. The ordinary is function; function is passage; passage is attainment. Attaining this, one is nearly there. Following this, though unaware of how it is so, is called the Dao. To exhaust one’s spirit and intelligence in unifying things yet remain unaware of their sameness is called "Morning Three." What is "Morning Three"? It is said: "The monkey keeper distributed chestnuts, saying, 'Three in the morning and four at dusk.' The monkeys were all enraged. He then said, 'Then four in the morning and three at dusk.' The monkeys were all pleased." Names and realities were diminished, yet joy and anger were employed—this, too, follows from this. Therefore, the sage harmonizes right and wrong and rests in the evenness of Heaven. This is called walking two paths.

The knowledge of the ancients reached its utmost. Where did it reach?

There are those who hold that things have never yet begun to exist—this is the utmost, the exhaustion of all, beyond which nothing can be added! Next are those who hold that things exist, yet boundaries have never yet arisen. Next are those who hold that boundaries exist, yet right and wrong have never yet appeared. When right and wrong become manifest, the Dao suffers loss. The Dao suffers loss, and attachment takes form. Is there truly gain and loss? Or is there truly neither gain nor loss? If there is gain and loss, then Master Zhao’s zither-playing exists; if there is neither gain nor loss, then Master Zhao’s zither-playing does not exist. Master Zhao’s zither-playing, Kuang’s wielding of the staff, and Master Hui’s leaning against the catalpa tree—these three men’s knowledge nearly reached perfection, each in their own excellence, and so their deeds are recorded at life’s end. Yet because they were fond of something, they differed from others; because they were fond of it, they sought to make it clear. But what they sought to clarify was not what could be clarified, and so they ended in the obscurity of "hard and white." And Master Zhao’s son ended with the threads of his father’s art, yet accomplished nothing his whole life. If this can be called accomplishment, then even I have accomplished something. If this cannot be called accomplishment, then neither things nor I have accomplished anything. Thus, the dazzling confusion of slippery doubt is what the sage despises. Instead of employing such things, one lodges them in the ordinary—this is called "illuminating through non-illumination."

Now, let me say something here: is it of the same kind as this, or not of the same kind? Whether of the same kind or not, all things are of the same kind, and so there is no difference from that. Nevertheless, let me try to speak of it. There is a beginning; there is a time before that beginning; there is a time before the time before that beginning. There is being; there is non-being; there is a time before non-being; there is a time before the time before non-being. Suddenly there is being and non-being, yet we do not know which of the two—being or non-being—truly is. Now I have already spoken, yet I do not know whether what I have spoken truly speaks of something or truly speaks of nothing.

In all the world, nothing is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small; no one lives longer than a child who dies young, yet Pengzu died prematurely. Heaven and Earth were born together with me, and the myriad things and I are one. Since we are already one, can there still be speech? Since I have already called it one, can there be no speech? One and speech make two; two and one make three. From this point onward, even the most skillful reckoner cannot reach the end—how much less can ordinary people! Therefore, from non-being to being, we reach three—how much more if we proceed from being to being! Do not proceed; abide in this!

The Dao has never had boundaries; words have never had constancy. Yet because of this, distinctions arise. Let me speak of these distinctions: there is left, there is right; there are ranks, there are duties; there are divisions, there are debates; there is competition, there is contention—these are called the eight virtues. Beyond the six directions, the sage acknowledges but does not discuss; within the six directions, the sage discusses but does not debate. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* records the intentions of the former kings, and the sage debates but does not argue. Thus, where there is division, there is also non-division; where there is debate, there is also non-debate.

One asks: "Why is this?" It is because the sage embraces it, while the multitude debate it to display to one another. Thus it is said: debate exists because there are things unseen. The great Dao is not named; great debate does not speak; great benevolence is not benevolent; great integrity is not modest; great courage does not harm. When the Dao is made manifest, it is no longer the Dao; when words are debated, they do not reach; when benevolence is constant, it does not succeed; when integrity is pure, it is not trusted; when courage is harmful, it does not succeed. These five are round yet nearly square! Therefore, to know where knowledge stops is perfection. Who knows the debate of no words, the Dao of no speaking? If one can know this, it is called the Heavenly Storehouse. Pour into it and it is never full; draw from it and it never runs dry, yet one does not know its source—this is called the Preserved Light.

Thus, in ancient times, Yao asked Shun: "I wish to attack Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao. When I face south, I feel uneasy. What is the reason for this?"

"How would I know?"
"Then do things have no knowledge?"
"How would I know?"

Now, let me ask you this: When people sleep in dampness, their waists ache and they become half-paralyzed—is that true of loaches? People eat the flesh of grass-fed and grain-fed animals; deer eat grass; centipedes delight in snakes; owls and crows relish mice. Of these four, which knows the proper taste? Monkeys pair with monkeys, deer mate with deer, loaches consort with fish. Mao Qiang and Li Ji were considered beautiful by men; but when fish saw them, they dove deep; when birds saw them, they flew high; when deer saw them, they bolted away. Of these four, which knows the true beauty of the world? From my perspective, the beginnings of benevolence and righteousness, the paths of right and wrong—all are tangled and confused. How could I distinguish them?"

Nie Que said: "If you do not know benefit and harm, does the Perfect Man also not know benefit and harm?"
Wang Ni replied: "The Perfect Man is divine! Though great marshes burn, he is not hot; though rivers freeze, he is not cold; though thunder splits mountains and whirlwinds shake the sea, he is not startled. One like this rides the clouds and qi, mounts the sun and moon, and roams beyond the four seas. Death and life do not alter him—how much less the beginnings of benefit and harm!"

Ququezi asked Changwuzi: "I have heard from the Master that the sage does not engage in affairs, does not pursue profit, does not avoid harm, does not seek, does not follow the Dao; speaks as though silent, is silent as though speaking, and roams beyond the dust and grime. The Master considered this reckless talk, but I see it as the practice of the wondrous Dao. What do you think?"
Changwuzi said: "Even the Yellow Emperor would be dazzled by these words—how could Confucius suffice! Why cling to sun and moon, embracing the cosmos? Let your lips meet, set aside confusion, and honor one another as servants. The multitude toil endlessly; the sage appears foolish and dull, blending the myriad ages into a single purity. All things are thus, mutually enfolding one another. How do I know that delight in life is not delusion? How do I know that aversion to death is not like a lost youth who does not know his way home?

Li Ji was the daughter of the border warden of Ai. When the state of Jin first obtained her, she wept until her collar was soaked; but once she reached the king’s palace, shared his bed, and ate fine meats, she regretted her tears. How do I know that the dead do not regret their former longing for life? Those who dream of drinking wake to weep; those who dream of weeping wake to hunt. While dreaming, they do not know it is a dream; within the dream, they may even interpret it. Only after waking do they know it was a dream. And only after the great awakening will they know that this was all a great dream. Yet fools believe themselves awake, busily distinguishing—lord and shepherd, how rigid! You and I are both dreams; when I say you are dreaming, I too am dreaming. Such words are called ‘uncanny reversal.’ Even after ten thousand ages, if a great sage appears who understands their meaning, it will be as though you met him morning and evening.

Suppose you and I debate: if you defeat me, and I do not defeat you, are you truly right and I truly wrong? If I defeat you, and you do not defeat me, am I truly right and you truly wrong? Is one of us right and the other wrong? Are both of us right or both wrong? You and I cannot know. Then people are inherently shrouded in darkness—whom shall we ask to judge? Shall we ask one who agrees with you? Since he already agrees with you, how can he judge? Shall we ask one who agrees with me? Since he already agrees with me, how can he judge? Shall we ask one who differs from both of us? Since he differs from both, how can he judge? Shall we ask one who agrees with both of us? Since he agrees with both, how can he judge? Then you, I, and others cannot know—must we wait for another?"

"What does it mean to harmonize with the heavenly equality?"
"It means: ‘Is it so? Is it not so? If it is truly so, then its difference from ‘not so’ requires no debate; if it is truly so, then its difference from ‘not so’ requires no debate.’ The mutual dependence of changing sounds is like their independence. Harmonize with the heavenly equality, follow the flowing transformations, and thus live out your years. Forget years, forget righteousness, be stirred by the boundless, and thus dwell in the boundless."

The Shadowy Doubt asked the Shadow: "Earlier you were walking, now you are still; earlier you were sitting, now you are standing. Why are you so without constancy?"

**Chapter 3: The Secret of Caring for Life**

My life has a limit, but knowledge has none. To pursue the limitless with the limited is perilous. And to pursue knowledge thus is even more perilous! In doing good, avoid seeking fame; in doing evil, avoid incurring punishment. Follow the central course as your guiding principle—this way you may preserve your body, fulfill your life, nurture your kin, and live out your years.

Cook Ding was carving an ox for Lord Wenhui. Where his hand touched, his shoulder leaned, his foot pressed, his knee braced—with a *hua* and a *xiang*, the blade sang, slicing *huo* through the flesh, never missing the rhythm, harmonizing with the "Mulberry Grove" dance, attaining the "Jingshou" melody.

Lord Wenhui exclaimed, "Ah! Excellent! How has your skill reached such heights?"

Cook Ding laid down his knife and replied, "What your servant loves is the Dao, which goes beyond mere skill. When I first began carving oxen, all I saw was the whole ox. After three years, I no longer saw the whole ox. Now, I meet it with my spirit rather than my eyes; my senses halt, but my spirit moves. Following the natural grain, I cleave the great seams, guide the blade through the great cavities, all according to its inherent structure. My knife has never touched the ligaments or tendons, much less the great bones! A good cook changes his knife every year—it is worn from cutting. An ordinary cook changes his knife every month—it is broken from hacking. But my knife has been in use for nineteen years, carving thousands of oxen, and its edge is still as if freshly whetted. For between the joints there are gaps, and the blade has no thickness. When what has no thickness enters where there is a gap, how vast the space for the blade to move! That is why after nineteen years, my knife’s edge is still as if freshly whetted. Nevertheless, whenever I come to a complex joint, I see the difficulty, I grow cautious, my gaze fixes, my movements slow. The blade moves ever so slightly, and *pffft*—the flesh falls apart like earth crumbling to the ground. Then I stand, knife in hand, look all around, savor the moment with satisfaction, wipe the blade clean, and put it away."

Lord Wenhui said, "Excellent! From Cook Ding’s words, I have learned how to care for life."

Gongwen Xuan saw the Right Master and was startled, saying, "What sort of man is this?"

"Yes."

Yan Hui said, "Where are you going?"
He replied, "I intend to go to Wei."
Confucius asked, "What will you do there?"
Yan Hui said, "I have heard that the Lord of Wei is in his prime, yet his conduct is willful. He treats his state lightly and does not recognize his faults. He treats the lives of his people as if they were nothing—so many die that the state measures them like marsh reeds, and the people have nowhere to turn. I once heard you say, ‘Leave a well-governed state; go to a disordered one. The physician’s gate is crowded with the sick.’ Reflecting on what I have heard, I hope that perhaps his state may yet be cured."

Confucius said, "Alas! You will likely go only to be punished! The Dao does not tolerate mixture—once mixed, it becomes excessive, and excess brings disorder. Disorder brings worry, and worry cannot be remedied. The perfected of old first established it within themselves before establishing it in others. When what is established within is settled, how could one have leisure to meddle in the conduct of violent men?

"Do you also know where virtue is swept away and from where knowledge arises? Virtue is swept away by fame, and knowledge arises from contention. Fame is the means by which men wound one another; knowledge is the tool of contention. Both are inauspicious instruments—not the way to act fully.

"Moreover, though one’s virtue be deep and trust unshaken, if one has not yet penetrated the qi of others, and though one’s fame be uncontentious, if one has not yet reached their hearts—yet to force upon them the language of benevolence and righteousness, the carpenter’s line of moral judgment, before violent men, is to make others resent what they see as one’s own beauty. "If you merely delight in the worthy and despise the unworthy, what use is it to seek to be different? If you do not even issue commands, the lords and princes will surely exploit your presence to vie for advantage. Confucius said, "Alas! How could that suffice?"
