The luminous arises from the obscure, order emerges from formlessness, spirit is born of the Dao, and physical form originates from essence—while the myriad things beget one another through form. Those with nine orifices are born from the womb; those with eight, from eggs. Their coming leaves no trace, their going no boundary; no gate, no chamber—yet they radiate boundlessly in all four directions. Those who wander thus possess supple limbs, penetrating insight, keen ears, and sharp eyes. Their minds do not toil, yet their responses know no limit. Heaven cannot but be high, Earth cannot but be vast; sun and moon cannot but move, and the myriad things cannot but flourish—such is the Dao!

Moreover, vast knowledge does not necessarily bring understanding, nor does eloquence guarantee wisdom. The sage has already settled this! That which, when augmented, does not increase, and when diminished, does not decrease—this is what the sage preserves. Profound as the sea, towering in its endless return to the beginning, it measures and sustains the myriad things without exhaustion. Thus the Dao of the noble person—does it lie outside these things? The myriad things all turn to it for sustenance, yet it is never depleted. Such is the Dao!

Within the Central Kingdom there is one who is neither yin nor yang, dwelling between Heaven and Earth, merely human for a time before returning to the Source. Viewed from its origin, life is but a fleeting coagulation of things. Though lifespans vary, how great is the difference? A mere instant—why debate the right and wrong of Yao and Jie? Fruits and melons have their patterns, human relations their complexities, yet these are but ways to order things. The sage encounters them without resistance, passes through them without clinging. To harmonize and respond is virtue; to coincide and respond is the Dao. From this arise emperors and kings.

Born between Heaven and Earth, one passes like a white colt through a gap—gone in an instant. Suddenly, vigorously, all things emerge; softly, smoothly, all things return. Transformed into life, then transformed into death. Living things mourn it, humankind grieves it. Yet Heaven’s quiver is unstrung, its celestial robe cast off. Twisting and turning, the soul departs, and the body follows. Thus the great return!

Not to be shaped by form, nor to shape the formless—this is what all people know, yet not what the realized strive for. This is the common discourse of the multitude. Those who have arrived do not debate; those who debate have not arrived. To perceive clearly yet find nothing to grasp, to speak without falling silent—this is not the great attainment. The Dao cannot be heard; to hear it is not as good as deafness: this is called the supreme attainment.

Dongguo Zi asked Zhuangzi: "Where does the so-called Dao reside?"
Zhuangzi said: "It is nowhere absent."
Dongguo Zi said: "You must specify."
Zhuangzi said: "It is in the ants."
Dongguo Zi said: "Why so lowly?"
Zhuangzi said: "It is in the weeds."
Dongguo Zi said: "Why even lower?"
Zhuangzi said: "It is in the tiles."
Dongguo Zi said: "Why more extreme still?"
Zhuangzi said: "It is in excrement and urine."
Dongguo Zi fell silent.

Zhuangzi said: "Your question fundamentally misses the mark. When Zheng and Huo asked the market inspector about the weight of a pig, the answer grew more precise with each lower part. You must not insist on a fixed locus—the Dao eludes nothing. The supreme Dao is like this, and so too is grand discourse. The three terms—pervasiveness, universality, and totality—differ in name but share the same reality; their intent is one. Let us wander together in the Palace of Nothingness, merging our discussions without end! Let us practice non-action together—serene and still, vast and clear, at ease and idle! My will is already empty; I go nowhere without knowing my destination, depart and return without knowing where I stop. I have come and gone without knowing my end, roaming in boundless expanse. Great knowledge enters here, yet knows no limit.

That which shapes things is not separate from things, yet things have boundaries—these are the boundaries of what shapes them. The boundary of the unbounded is the boundary of what is not a boundary. We speak of fullness and emptiness, decline and decay, yet what is full and empty is not fullness and emptiness; what declines and decays is not decline and decay. What has root and branch is not root and branch; what accumulates and disperses is not accumulation and dispersal."

Nü Ke studied with Shen Nong under Old Dragon Ji. One day, Shen Nong was resting with his head on a table, the door closed, napping in broad daylight. Nü Ke pushed open the door and entered, saying: "Old Dragon is dead!"
Shen Nong, still leaning on the table, grasped his staff and rose. Then, letting it clatter to the ground, he laughed and said: "Heaven knew my stubbornness and sloth, so it cast me aside and let him die. Alas, Master! You have died without ever unleashing your wild words!"

Yan Gangdiao heard this and said: "The embodiment is what all gentlemen under Heaven are bound to. Now, in the Dao, one has not even attained a ten-thousandth part of the tip of an autumn hair, yet still knows to conceal one’s wild words—how much more so, then, for one who embodies the Dao! Thereupon Tai Qing asked Wu Qiong: "Do you know the Dao?"
Wu Qiong said: "I do not know."
Then he asked Wu Wei, who said: "I know the Dao."
Tai Qing asked: "In your knowing the Dao, is there a method?"
Wu Wei said: "There is."
Tai Qing asked: "What is this method like?"
Wu Wei said: "I know the Dao can be esteemed, can be debased, can be gathered, can be dispersed—this is the method by which I know the Dao."

Tai Qing took these words and asked Wu Shi: "If this is so, then between Wu Qiong’s not-knowing and Wu Wei’s knowing, which is right and which is wrong?"
Wu Shi said: "Not-knowing is profound; knowing is shallow. Not-knowing is internal; knowing is external."

Thereupon Tai Qing sighed deeply and said: "Is not-knowing then knowing? Is knowing then not-knowing? Who knows the knowing of not-knowing?"
Wu Shi said: "The Dao cannot be heard—what is heard is not it. The Dao cannot be seen—what is seen is not it. The Dao cannot be spoken—what is spoken is not it. Do you know that the formless cannot be formed? The Dao cannot be named."

Wu said: "One who is asked about the Dao and responds does not know the Dao. Even one who asks about the Dao has not heard the Dao. The Dao admits no questions; questions admit no answers. To question what admits no questions is to question the inscrutable. To answer what admits no answers is to lack inwardness. Confronting the inscrutable with what lacks inwardness—such a one outwardly does not observe the cosmos, inwardly does not know the Great Beginning. Thus he does not pass beyond Kunlun, nor roam in the Great Void."

Guang Yao asked Wu You: "Do you exist, Master? Or do you not exist?"
Guang Yao could not frame his question, and gazed intently at Wu You’s form—vast and empty. He looked at him all day yet saw nothing; listened yet heard nothing; grasped yet could not seize him.

Guang Yao said: "This is perfection! Who could attain this? I can attain being and non-being, yet I have not attained non-being of non-being. How could one reach this from non-existence?"

The master smith of Great Horse, though eighty years old, never missed by a hair’s breadth. Great Horse said: "Is it skill, or is there a Dao to it?"

The smith replied: "I have my discipline. At twenty, I took delight in forging hooks, and to all else I was blind—nothing but hooks did I scrutinize. What I employed was the unutilized, thereby prolonging its use. How much more so for that which is never not used! What thing does not draw upon it?"

Ran Qiu asked Confucius: "Can one know what preceded heaven and earth?"
Confucius said: "One can. The past is like the present."
Ran Qiu, failing to grasp the answer, withdrew.

The next day, he returned and said: "Yesterday I asked, 'Can one know what preceded heaven and earth?' You replied, 'One can. The past is like the present.' Yesterday I saw clearly, but today I am benighted. May I ask what this means?"
Confucius said: "Yesterday’s clarity came from the spirit first receiving it. Today’s benightedness comes from seeking it with what is not spirit! There is no past, no present, no beginning, no end. Before you existed, could you have had descendants?"

Ran Qiu did not respond.
Confucius said: "Enough! No further answer is needed. Do not use life to give birth to death, nor use death to give birth to life. Do life and death depend on one another? All share a single body. Was there something that existed before heaven and earth? That which gives rise to things is not itself a thing. Things do not emerge before that which gives rise to them—yet there are things. Since there are things, there is no end. The sage’s love for others never ends, for he draws from this principle."

Yan Yuan asked Confucius: "I once heard you say, 'Do not send off, do not welcome.' I venture to wander in this."
Confucius said: "The people of old transformed outwardly but remained unchanging within. The people of today transform inwardly but remain unchanging without. Those who transform with things are one with the unchanging. How can one be at ease with change or non-change? How can one be at ease with aligning with them? One must align with them without excess.

In the gardens of the Shiwei clan, the parks of the Yellow Emperor, the halls of Lord Yu, the chambers of Tang and Wu—gentlemen, like the masters of the Ru and Mo schools, still used right and wrong to vie with one another. How much more so the people of today! The sage dwells among things without harming them. One who does not harm things cannot be harmed by them. Only one who harms nothing can send off and welcome others.

Mountains and forests! Marshes and wilds! They make me joyful and glad! But before the joy is complete, sorrow follows. When sorrow and joy come, I cannot resist them; when they depart, I cannot stop them. Alas! People of the world merely take things as transient lodgings.

They know what they encounter but not what they do not; they know what they can do but not what they cannot. Those without knowledge or ability are what people cannot avoid. To strive for what people cannot—is this not also lamentable?

Ultimate words discard words; ultimate action discards action. To equalize what knowledge knows is shallow indeed!"

Guang Yao asked Wu You: "Do you exist, Master? Or do you not exist?"
Guang Yao could not frame his question, and gazed intently at Wu You’s form—vast and empty. He looked at him all day yet saw nothing; listened yet heard nothing; grasped yet could not seize him.

Guang Yao said: "This is perfection! Who could attain this? I can attain being and non-being, yet I have not attained non-being of non-being. How could one reach this from non-existence?"

**Chapter Twenty-Three: Gengsang Chu**

Among the disciples of Lao Dan was one named Gengsang Chu, who had partially grasped the Master’s Dao. He went north to dwell in the mountains of Weilei. Those among his retainers who were scheming and calculating he sent away; those among his concubines who were ostentatiously kind he kept at a distance. Only the dull and the clumsy remained with him, and the restless and the harried served him.

After three years, Weilei flourished. The people of Weilei said to one another: “When Master Gengsang first arrived, we found him strange and unsettling. Now, when we reckon our days, we find them lacking, but when we reckon our years, we find them abundant. He must be a sage! Why do you not join together to offer him sacrifices as to an ancestral spirit, to honor him as you would the gods of soil and grain?”

When Gengsang Chu heard this, he turned southward, his countenance troubled. His disciples were perplexed. Gengsang Chu said: “Why are you puzzled by me? When the spring qi stirs, the hundred grasses sprout; when autumn arrives in due season, the ten thousand treasures ripen. Are spring and autumn themselves responsible for this? The Dao of Heaven has simply run its course. I have heard that the perfected person dwells like a corpse in a walled chamber, while the common people run wild, not knowing where to turn. Now these petty folk of Weilei secretly wish to place me among the worthy, offering me sacrificial vessels. Am I truly the sort of person to be measured thus? This is why I cannot let go of the words of Lao Dan.”

His disciples said: “This is not so.”

Nanrong Chu straightened himself and sat upright, saying: “As for one like me, Chu, my years are already advanced—how then may I entrust myself to this learning and attain these words?”

The Master said: “Preserve your form whole, embrace your life, and let not your thoughts and cares flutter restlessly. If you do these three things for three years, then you may attain these words.”

Nanrong Chu said: “The eye and the form—I do not know their difference, yet the blind cannot see themselves. The ear and the form—I do not know their difference, yet the deaf cannot hear themselves. The heart and the form—I do not know their difference, yet the mad cannot grasp themselves. The form and the form are surely distinct, yet why do things come between them? I seek to unite them but cannot attain it. Now you tell me, Chu: ‘Preserve your form whole, embrace your life, let not your thoughts and cares flutter.’ I strain to hear the Dao, yet it only reaches my ears!”

Gengsangzi said: “My words are exhausted. The running bee cannot transform the hollyhock caterpillar; the Yue chicken cannot hatch the swan’s egg—yet the common hen can! The hen and the hen: their virtue is not different. That some can and some cannot is simply that their capacities are inherently great or small. Now my capacity is small—it is just enough to transform you. Why do you not go south to see Laozi?”

Nanrong Chu gathered provisions and, after seven days and seven nights, arrived at Laozi’s abode. Laozi said: “Have you come from the region of Chu?” Nanrong Chu replied: “Yes.” Laozi said: “Why have you brought so many people with you?” Nanrong Chu looked around in alarm. Laozi said: “Do you not understand what I meant?” Nanrong Chu bowed his head in shame, then raised it and sighed: “Now I have forgotten my answer to your question.”

Laozi said: “What do you mean?” Nanrong Chu said: “If I do not know, people call me foolish. If I know, I am filled with sorrow. Without ren, I harm others; with ren, I bring sorrow upon myself. Without yi, I injure others; with yi, I bring sorrow upon myself. How can I escape this? These words are what trouble me, Chu. I wish to ask you through the example of Chu.”

Laozi said: “Just now, I saw it in the space between your brows and lashes—I had already grasped you. Now you speak again and confirm it. You are like one who has lost his parents, raising a pole to search the sea. You are a lost man—how bewildered! You wish to return to your true nature but have no way in. How pitiful!”

Nanrong Chu asked to enter and rest in a dwelling. He summoned what he loved and cast aside what he hated. For ten days he brooded, then saw Laozi again. Laozi said: “You have cleansed yourself—how deeply troubled you still are! Yet within, there still lingers something foul. Those bound by external constraints cannot be grasped by force; they must be inwardly restrained. Those bound by internal constraints cannot be seized by deception; they must be outwardly restrained. Those bound by both internal and external constraints—even the power of the Dao and virtue cannot uphold them, let alone those who wander beyond the Dao!”

Nanrong Chu said: “When a villager is ill, another villager asks after him. If the sick one can describe his illness, then though he speaks of it, his illness is as if it were not an illness. As for my hearing of the great Dao, it is like taking medicine that only worsens the sickness. I wish only to hear the classic of preserving life.”

Laozi said: “The classic of preserving life—can you embrace the One? Can you not lose it? Can you know good and ill fortune without divination? Can you stop? Can you cease? Can you set aside what others seek and seek it within yourself? Can you be free and unconstrained? Can you be open and unassuming? Can you be like a child? A child wails all day yet its throat does not grow hoarse—such is the perfection of harmony. It clutches all day yet its hand does not cramp—such is the sharing of its power. It gazes all day yet its eyes do not blink—its focus is not on externals. It walks without knowing where it goes, dwells without knowing what it does, moves with things in perfect accord, riding their waves. This is the classic of preserving life.”

Nanrong Chu said: “Then is this the virtue of the perfected person?” Laozi said: “It is not.”

When the mind is settled in great peace, it radiates the light of heaven. One who radiates this light is seen as human. Those who cultivate themselves now possess constancy. Constancy is what others abandon and heaven aids. What people abandon is called the people of heaven; what heaven aids is called the son of heaven.

The learner studies what cannot be learned; the doer acts in what cannot be acted; the debater argues what cannot be argued. To know when to stop at what cannot be known—this is the utmost. If there is any who does not conform to this, the balance of heaven will undo them.

Prepare things to sustain the form, conceal the unforeseen to nurture the mind, and honor the center to reach the other. If, despite this, myriad evils still arrive, they are from heaven, not from man—they cannot disturb completion or enter the sacred chamber. The sacred chamber has its support, yet one does not know what supports it, nor can it be grasped.

When sincerity stirs within and manifests, each manifestation may be amiss. Once karma takes hold, it does not release, and with each turn, one strays further. To do evil in the light is for people to condemn; to do evil in the dark is for ghosts to condemn. Only one who is clear about people and clear about ghosts can walk alone.

Within the contract, act without name; beyond the contract, aspire to costly expectations. Acting without name is the way of the common; aspiring to costly expectations is the way of the merchant. People see their striving and deem it grand. Yet one who exhausts things is entered by things; one who contends with things cannot even contain themselves—how could they contain others? One who cannot contain others has no kinship; one with no kinship is forsaken by all.

No weapon is sharper than the will; even the finest blade is inferior. No foe is greater than yin and yang—there is no escape from them between heaven and earth. It is not yin and yang that harm, but the heart that employs them.

The Dao flows—its division is its completion, its completion is its undoing. What is despised in division is that it leads to preparation; what is despised in preparation is that it implies possession. To emerge without origin, to enter without aperture—possessing substance yet no place, having length yet no root or tip. That which emerges without aperture possesses substance. Possessing substance yet no place is space; having length yet no root or tip is time.

There is existence, there is death; there is existence, there is entry. To enter and exit without revealing form is called the Gate of Heaven. The Gate of Heaven is non-being—all things emerge from non-being. Being does not take being as being; it must emerge from non-being, and non-being itself is not a non-being. The sage conceals himself herein.

The ancients—how far their knowledge reached! Where did it reach? Some held that there had never yet been anything—this is the utmost, the limit, beyond which nothing can be added. Next were those who acknowledged things, seeing life as loss and death as return—thus they made distinctions. Then came those who said that at first there was nothing, then suddenly there was life, and life swiftly turned to death. They took non-being as the head, life as the body, and death as the tail. Whoever knows the unity of existence, non-existence, death, and life—I befriend them. Though these three differ, they belong to the same clan.

The sacrificial meats of the winter sacrifice can be scattered, yet they cannot be scattered. If there is indeed substance, one uses oneself as the measure, making others conform to one’s standards and even dying to uphold them. This shifting is the way of people today—like the cicada and the fledgling bird, they are the same in their sameness.

To tread on a market-goer’s foot, one apologizes with haughty words; to a brother, with gentle ones; to a parent, one says nothing at all. Thus it is said: The utmost ritual has no "no"; the utmost righteousness does not treat things as things; the utmost knowledge does not scheme; the utmost benevolence has no kinship; the utmost trust dispenses with metal.

Dispel the turbulence of the will, untangle the knots of the heart, cast off the burdens of virtue, and clear the blockages of the Dao. The movement of nature is called *wei*; the artificiality of *wei* is called loss.

Knowledge is contact; wisdom is planning. What the wise do not know is like a sidelong glance.

Movement from inevitability is called virtue; movement without self is governance. Names oppose each other, yet realities align.

Yi excelled at hitting the smallest mark but was clumsy at preventing others from praising him. The sage excels at Heaven but is clumsy with people. Only the whole person can excel at Heaven while being adept with people.

Though creatures may act as creatures, they act as Heaven. Does the whole person despise Heaven? Do they despise the Heaven in people? How much more, then, the Heaven in oneself and others!

When a sparrow comes to Yi, Yi must catch it—this is fate. If one takes the world as a cage, no sparrow can escape. Thus, Tang caged Yi Yin with human means, and Duke Mu of Qin caged Bai Li Xi with five sheepskins. Therefore, nothing can be caged except by means of what it loves.

The cripple draws boundaries, indifferent to external praise or blame. The convict climbs high without fear, having forgotten life and death. One who recovers from stumbling without resentment has forgotten others; forgetting others, one thereby becomes Heaven.

Thus, one who is revered yet feels no joy, or insulted yet feels no anger—only one in harmony with Heaven’s accord is so. Anger arises from non-anger; action arises from non-action.

To still the mind, calm the qi; to be spirit-like, follow the heart. In action, to be fitting is to act from inevitability. The way of the sage lies in the category of inevitability.

**Chapter Twenty-Four: Xu Wu Gui** *(from Book Eight, "Middle")*

Xu Wu Gui, through Nü Shang, was received by Marquis Wu of Wei. The marquis greeted him, saying, "Master, you must be weary—exhausted by the toils of mountain and forest, and thus willing to meet with me."

Xu Wu Gui replied, "It is I who weary you, my lord—what weariness have you for me? If you indulge your desires and prolong your likes and dislikes, the natural emotions of your nature will sicken. If you suppress your desires and cast off likes and dislikes, your ears and eyes will sicken. I weary you, my lord—what weariness have you for me?"

The marquis, startled, made no reply. After a moment, Xu Wu Gui continued, "Let me tell you, my lord—I read the signs in dogs. The inferior kind stops when its belly is full—this is the virtue of the wildcat..."

Commoners with daily work are diligent; those skilled in tools and machines are robust. Those who hoard no wealth worry the greedy; those who lack prominence grieve the boastful. Followers of power and things delight in change. When the times call for use, they cannot be without action—all these align with the seasons, not with the constancy of transformation. They exhaust their nature and form, sinking into the ten thousand things, never to return.

Zhuangzi said, "If an archer hits the mark without aiming beforehand, is he a good shot? If so, then everyone in the world is Yi—is that acceptable?" Huizi said nothing. Zhuangzi continued, "The world has no shared truth, and each affirms what they affirm. If so, then everyone in the world is Yao—is that acceptable?" Huizi said nothing.

Zhuangzi said, "Then among the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, and Bingists—five in all with you—who is truly right? Or is it like Lu Ju? His disciple said, 'I have grasped the Master’s Way! I can boil a cauldron in winter and make ice in summer!' Lu Ju replied, 'This merely summons yang with yang and yin with yin—it is not what I call the Way. Let me show you my Way.' Thereupon, he tuned two zithers, placing one in the hall and one in the chamber. When the *gong* note was struck, the *jiao* note resonated; when the *jue* note was struck, the *jiao* note responded—their tones harmonized. But if one string were adjusted so that it no longer fit the five notes, and all twenty-five strings were struck, the sounds would not differ, yet the ruler of tones would already be present. Is it like this?"

Huizi said, "Now the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, and Bingists all debate, clashing with words and overpowering with voices, yet none admit they are wrong—how is this?" Zhuangzi said, "A man of Qi sent his son to Song to serve as a gatekeeper, but did not provide him with proper provisions. When he sought a bronze bell, he bound it; when he sought Tang’s son, he never left the domain—such are the remnants of folly! A man sent as a gatekeeper to lodge in another’s home, who in the dead of night fights with the boatman when no one is around, has not yet left the shore yet stirs up resentment."

Zhuangzi was attending a funeral and passed by Huizi’s grave. Turning to his followers, he said, "A man of Ying had a speck of plaster on the tip of his nose no thicker than a fly’s wing. He called a craftsman to remove it. The craftsman swung his axe with the force of the wind, listening as he struck, removing all the plaster without harming the nose. The man of Ying stood unmoved. When the Lord of Song Yuan heard of this, he summoned the craftsman and said, 'Try doing it for me.' The craftsman replied, 'Your servant once could do this, but the material for my skill has long been dead.' Since Huizi’s death, I have had no material for my skill, no one to speak with."

Guan Zhong fell ill, and Duke Huan asked him, "Your illness is grave. If I may ask, when it reaches its worst, to whom should I entrust the state?" Guan Zhong said, "Whom does the Duke wish to appoint?" The Duke said, "Bao Shuya." Guan Zhong replied, "He is not suitable. He is a man of purity and integrity, a good scholar. Those who are not like him, he does not associate with. Moreover, once he hears of another’s fault, he never forgets it. If you appoint him to govern, above he will probe the ruler, and below he will oppose the people. It will not be long before he offends you."

The Duke said, "Then who is suitable?" Guan Zhong replied, "If you must choose, then Xi Peng is suitable. His character is such that he forgets those above and distances himself from those below. He feels ashamed that he is not like the Yellow Emperor and pities those who are not like himself. To share virtue with others is called sageliness; to share wealth with others is called worthiness. To rule others with worthiness never wins their hearts; to humble oneself with worthiness never fails to win them. In governing the state, he does not hear what he should not; in managing his household, he does not see what he should not. If you must choose, then Xi Peng is suitable."

When the Yellow Emperor sought to meet the Great Hidden One on Mount Juci, Fang Ming drove his chariot, Chang Yu rode at his side, Zhang Ruo and Xi Peng led the horses, and Kun Gu Ji followed in the rear carriage. When they reached the wilds of Xiangcheng, the Seven Sages all lost their way and had nowhere to ask directions. They happened upon a boy herding horses and asked him the way. 'Do you know Mount Juci?' they said. 'I do,' he replied. 'Do you know where the Great Hidden One dwells?'"

The King of Wu floated upon the river and ascended the Mountain of the Macaques. The macaques, seeing him, in alarm abandoned their perches and fled, vanishing into the dense thickets. One, however, slithered and scratched, displaying its cunning before the king. The king shot at it, but the macaque nimbly caught the swift arrow. The king then ordered his attendants to hasten and shoot it, and the macaque was seized and killed. The king turned to his minister Yan Buyi and said, "This macaque, priding itself on its skill and relying on its agility, dared to mock me—thus it met its doom. Take heed! Alas, never let your demeanor make others proud."

Yan Buyi returned home and took Dong Wu as his teacher. He uprooted his arrogance, abandoned pleasure, and declined honors. After three years, the people of the state praised him.

Nanbo Ziqi leaned upon his armrest and sat, gazing upward and sighing. Yan Chengzi entered and said, "Master, you are the most extraordinary of beings—can your form be made like withered bones, and can your heart truly be made like dead ashes?"

He replied, "Once I dwelled in a mountain cave. At that time, when the fields and crops caught a single glimpse of me, the multitudes of Qi all thrice congratulated one another."

I must first possess it, and thus they know it; I must first offer it for sale, and thus they sell it. If I do not possess it, how can they know it? If I do not sell it, how can they peddle it? Alas! I grieve for those who lose themselves, and I grieve yet more for those who grieve for them. And I grieve still further for those who grieve over the grief of others—ever receding into the distance!

When Confucius traveled to Chu, the king of Chu offered him wine. Sunshu Ao stood holding the goblet, while Shinan Yiliao received the wine and made a libation, saying, "How ancient are these words!" Then he said, "I, Qiu, have heard of the speech that is without words, yet have never spoken it—until now. Shinan Yiliao juggles balls, a puzzle hard to unravel; Sunshu Ao sleeps sweetly, holding a feather fan, while the people of Ying lay down their weapons. I wish I had a beak three feet long!"

That is called the Dao that is not the Dao, the eloquence that is without words. Thus virtue gathers in the unity of the Dao, and speech rests where knowledge cannot reach—this is perfection. What the Dao unifies, virtue shares; what knowledge cannot know, eloquence cannot express. Names like "Confucian" or "Mohist" bring only misfortune.

Thus the sea does not refuse the eastward flow—this is the utmost in greatness. A person embraces heaven and earth, bestowing blessings upon the world, yet none know their name. Therefore, in life they bear no rank, in death no posthumous title; they accumulate no wealth, nor do they seek fame—this is called the Great Person. A dog is not good because it barks well, nor is a person worthy because they speak well—how much less so for the great! To be great is not enough to be called great, how much less so for virtue! Yet greatness is complete—none surpasses heaven and earth. But what do they seek? And yet they are complete!

Those who know completeness seek nothing, lose nothing, discard nothing, and do not exchange themselves for things. Turning inward, they are inexhaustible; following the ancient, they do not wear away—this is the way of the Great Person!

Ziqi had eight sons. He lined them up before him and summoned Jiufang Yin, saying, "Examine my sons for me and tell me which is most auspicious." Jiufang Yin replied, "Kun is auspicious." Ziqi started in surprise and joy, asking, "In what way?" He replied, "Kun will share the ruler’s table for the rest of his life." Ziqi’s face fell, and tears streamed down as he said, "What has my son done to reach such an extreme?" Jiufang Yin said, "One who shares the ruler’s table bestows blessings upon three clans—how much more so upon parents! Now that you have heard this and weep, you reject good fortune. Your son is auspicious, but you are not."

Ziqi said, "Yin, how could you understand? Is Kun truly auspicious? His fate is bound to meat and wine, entering only through nose and mouth—how can one know its origin? I have never herded sheep, yet a ewe was born in the inner chamber; I have never hunted, yet a quail hatched in the rafters. If this is not strange, then what is? What I share with my sons is wandering in the realm of heaven and earth. With them, I roam in joy beneath the sky and feast upon the earth. I do not involve them in affairs, nor in schemes, nor in strangeness. With them, I ride the sincerity of heaven and earth, not entangling them with things. With them, I drift and flow, not binding them to the concerns of the world. Yet now, this has brought worldly recompense!

Whenever there are strange omens, there must be strange conduct—how perilous! This is not the fault of my sons or me, but of heaven! That is why I weep."

Before long, Kun was sent to Yan. Bandits seized him on the road. Selling him whole would be difficult, but maiming him would make it easy. So they cut off his feet and sold him in Qi, where he ended up in the employ of Duke Qu, eating meat for the rest of his life.

Nie Que met Xu You and asked, "Where are you going?" He replied, "I am fleeing Yao." "What do you mean?" Xu You said, "Yao is so earnestly benevolent—yet I fear he will become a laughingstock to the world. Later generations may even turn to cannibalism! The people are not hard to gather: love them, benefit them, and they come; praise them, and they are encouraged. But impose what they hate, and they scatter. Love and benefit arise from benevolence and righteousness, yet those who discard benevolence and righteousness are few, while those who profit from them are many. The practice of benevolence and righteousness lacks sincerity—it is but a vessel for the greedy and predatory. Thus, when one person’s judgment controls the world’s benefits, it is like a single glance. Yao knows that worthy men benefit the world, but he does not know they also harm it—only those outside worthiness understand this."

There are those who are *nuan shu*, those who are *ru xu*, and those who are *juan lou*.

The *nuan shu* learn the words of a single master, then glow with self-satisfaction, believing themselves complete—yet they do not know that nothing has truly begun. Thus they are called *nuan shu*.

The *ru xu* are like lice on a pig: sparse bristles become their vast palace and park. The curves of hooves and knees, the spaces between teats and thighs—these they take as safe dwellings and advantageous places. They do not know that the butcher, with a single wave of his arm, spreads straw and wields fire, and they will be roasted along with the pig. They advance and retreat within their domain—this is what is called *ru xu*.

The *juan lou* is like Shun. Mutton does not long for ants, but ants long for mutton—because mutton is rank. Shun had rank conduct, and the people delighted in him. Thus, when he moved to Chengdu, by the time he reached the ruins of Deng, a hundred thousand households had gathered. Yao, hearing of Shun’s worthiness, raised him from the barren land, saying, "I hope to receive his blessings." Shun was raised from the barren land, and though his years grew long and his hearing and sight waned, he could not retire. This is what is called *juan lou*.

The divine person detests the crowd’s arrival, for when the crowd arrives, they do not harmonize; when they do not harmonize, no benefit comes of it.

Thus, one who is neither overly intimate nor overly distant, who embraces virtue and warms harmony to align with all under heaven—this is called the *True Person*. To ants, wisdom is discarded; to fish, calculation is fitting; to sheep, intent is abandoned.

With the eye, one sees the eye; with the ear, one hears the ear; with the heart, one returns to the heart. Such a one is level as a plumb line, and in change, follows the natural course. The *True Person* of old! With heaven, they await humanity; they do not force humanity into heaven. The *True Person* of old! In gaining it, they live; in losing it, they die. In gaining it, they die; in losing it, they live.

Medicines—such as aconite, platycodon, chicken pox, and pig’s rot—are the tools of emperors. How can they all be enumerated! Goujian, with a thousand shields and spears, took refuge at Kuaiji. Only Wen Zhong could know how ruin would become survival, yet even he did not know why his own person would suffer sorrow.

Thus it is said: The owl’s eye has its proper place; the crane’s leg has its proper length—severing them brings sorrow. Thus it is said: When wind passes over a river, it diminishes it; when the sun passes over a river, it diminishes it. If only wind and sun were to guard the river together, the river would deem them no disturbance at all, for it relies on its source and flows onward.

Thus, water’s adherence to earth is precise; its adherence to humanity, and things’ adherence to things, are likewise precise. The eye’s reliance on clarity is perilous; the ear’s reliance on acuity is perilous; the heart’s pursuit of desire is perilous. All faculties, when bound to their storehouses, become perilous, and once peril is formed, it cannot be swiftly remedied. Disaster’s growth is dense and clustered; its reversal depends on merit; its fruition awaits time.

That people regard this as their treasure—is it not lamentable! Thus, the ruin of states and the slaughter of people never cease, for they do not inquire into the cause. The foot’s tread upon the earth is firm, yet it relies on what it does not tread to walk broadly. Humanity’s knowledge is scant, yet it relies on what it does not know to comprehend heaven.

To know the Great Oneness, the Great Yin, the Great Vision, the Great Equality, the Great Square, the Great Faith, the Great Constancy—this is perfection! The Great Oneness unites them; the Great Yin dissolves them; the Great Vision sees them; the Great Equality follows them; the Great Square embodies them; the Great Faith verifies them; the Great Constancy upholds them.

There is the Heavenly Cycle, the Illuminating Obscurity, the Pivot of Beginning, the That-and-This. In dissolving them, one seems not to dissolve; in knowing them, one seems not to know. Only by not knowing does one come to know. In questioning them, one cannot set limits, yet cannot be without limits. Though tangled and slippery, they hold truth. Past and present alternate, yet cannot be diminished—can this not be called great clarification?

Why not simply inquire into this, and what confusion remains? To be confused by what is not confusing, and return to what is not confusing—this is the highest non-confusion.

Zeyang traveled to Chu, and Yi Jie spoke of him to the king, but the king did not summon him. Yi Jie returned home. Pengyang met Wang Guo and said, "Why did the Master not recommend me to the king?" Wang Guo replied, "I am not as good as Gong Yuxiu."

Pengyang asked, "What does Gong Yuxiu do?" Wang Guo said, "In winter, he spears turtles in the river; in summer, he rests in the mountain thickets. If someone passes by and asks, he says, ‘This is my dwelling.’ Yi Jie could not match him—how much less could I! I am not even Yi Jie’s equal.

"Yi Jie’s character is virtuous and wise, yet he does not presume. His interactions with the spirit-like are steadfast, firmly rooted in the realm of wealth and honor. If not for mutual aid in virtue, they would only erode one another. The frozen borrow clothes from spring; the overheated turn back to winter’s cold wind.

"His demeanor is dignified and stern. In matters of punishment, he pardons none, like a tiger. If not for a cunning man’s rectification of virtue, who could sway him? Thus, when the sage is in poverty, he makes his family forget their want; when he is in prominence, he makes kings and lords forget their ranks and transform into humility.

Thus, sometimes without speaking, he harmonizes others; standing beside them, he transforms them, as naturally as the proper relationship between father and son. Such is his way of returning. Dwelling in stillness, he observes the scope of his influence. His effect on the human heart is so distant.

"Thus, it is said, ‘Await Gong Yuxiu.’"

The sage’s comprehension is thorough and all-encompassing, yet he does not know it as such—it is his nature. He responds to fate and acts, taking heaven as his teacher, while others follow and name him. Anxious in knowledge, his actions seldom endure. When they cease, what then?

One born beautiful is given a mirror by others; if not told, they do not know their beauty surpasses others. Whether they know or do not know, hear or do not hear, their joy is endless, and others’ fondness for them is likewise endless—it is their nature.

The sage’s love for people is such that others name it for him; if told, they do not know his love for people. Whether they know or do not know, hear or do not hear, his love is endless, and people’s contentment in it is likewise endless—it is his nature.

An old state, an old capital—gazing upon them brings delight. Even if nine-tenths were overgrown with hills, grass, and trees, one would still delight in them. How much more so when seeing and hearing what is familiar, like a ten-fathom banner amidst the crowd!

Ran Xiangshi grasped the center of the ring and followed completion, moving with things without end or beginning, without nearness or time. One who daily transforms with things is one with them. Why ever abandon this?

To take heaven as one’s teacher and yet fail to do so, to be enslaved with things—how can one make this one’s task? The sage has never begun, never begun with humanity, never begun with beginning, never begun with things. They move with the world without ceasing, their actions complete yet not excessive. Zilu went to look, but the house was empty.

The warden of Changwu asked Zilao: *"In governing, do not be reckless; in ordering the people, do not be careless. When Zhuangzi heard of this, he said: *"Nowadays, those who cultivate their bodies and order their minds often resemble what the warden describes. Boju studied under Lao Dan and said, "I request to wander the world."
Lao Dan replied, "Enough! The world is everywhere the same."
Boju asked again, and Lao Dan said, "Where will you begin?"
He replied, "I will begin in Qi."

Arriving in Qi, he saw a man who had been executed. He pushed forward, straightened the body, removed his court robes to cover it, wailed to Heaven, and wept, saying: "You! You! The world suffers great calamity—why must you alone be the first to meet it? They say, *'Do not steal! Do not kill!'* Yet once honor and disgrace are established, one sees what brings suffering; once wealth and property are amassed, one sees what sparks strife. Now, to establish what brings people suffering, to amass what sparks their strife, to exhaust their bodies without respite—how could one hope to avoid reaching this point?

In ancient times, those who ruled over others took success as belonging to the people and failure as their own; they took uprightness as belonging to the people and crookedness as their own. Thus, if even one person lost their proper form, they would withdraw and blame themselves. Now, it is not so: they conceal their deeds, feigning ignorance of the people’s folly; they impose great difficulties yet punish those who dare not comply; they heap heavy burdens yet penalize those who cannot bear them; they lengthen the path yet execute those who do not reach the end. When the people’s strength is exhausted, they resort to deception to sustain it. With falsehoods multiplying daily, how can scholars and commoners not also resort to falsehood?

When strength is insufficient, one resorts to pretense; when wisdom is insufficient, one resorts to deceit; when wealth is insufficient, one resorts to... Who can be held accountable for the deeds of theft and banditry?"

Little Knowledge asked Great Master Tiáo: "What is meant by 'village words'?" Great Master Tiáo said: "A village combines ten surnames to form its customs, unites differences into sameness, and disperses sameness into differences. Now, if you point to the hundred parts of a horse and cannot obtain the horse, yet the horse stands before you, it is because you call the hundred parts a horse. Thus, hills accumulate the lowly to become high; rivers combine waters to become great; the great man unites all to become impartial. What enters from without has a master but is not grasped; what issues from within has a norm but is not resisted. The four seasons have distinct qi, yet Heaven does not bestow favor, and so the year is completed; offices have distinct duties, yet the ruler does not show partiality, and so the state is well-governed; the civil and martial virtues of the great man are not bestowed, and so his power is complete; the myriad things have distinct principles, yet the Dao does not show partiality, and so it is nameless. Nameless, it is non-action; through non-action, there is nothing it does not do. Time has endings and beginnings; the world has changes and transformations. Fortune and misfortune flow ceaselessly, sometimes thwarting what should be fitting, sometimes following different paths; what is corrected may still err. Compared to a great marsh, all materials find their measure; observed in a great mountain, trees and stones share the same ground. This is what is meant by 'village words.'" Little Knowledge said: "Then can this be called the Dao?" Great Master Tiáo said: "No. The number of things is not limited to ten thousand, yet we call them 'the ten thousand things' because we name and refer to them by their multitude. Thus, Heaven and Earth are the greatest of forms; yin and yang are the greatest of qi; the Dao is their impartiality. To name and refer to it by its greatness is permissible, but to claim you have grasped it—how could you compare to it? If you argue thus, it would be like comparing dogs and horses—far from sufficient."

Little Knowledge said: "Within the four seas, within the six directions, where do the myriad things arise?" Great Master Tiáo said: "Yin and yang illuminate and cover each other, govern and regulate each other; the four seasons succeed one another, give birth to and destroy each other. Desires and aversions, departures and approaches arise from this; the union of male and female becomes customary through this. Safety and danger alternate; fortune and misfortune give birth to each other; urgency and leisure rub against each other; gathering and scattering complete each other. These are the names and realities that can be recorded, the essences that can be noted. Following the order of succession, the mutual employment of bridging movements, exhaustion returns to beginning, end returns to start—this is what things inherently possess. What words can exhaust, what knowledge can reach, is merely the limits of things. Those who perceive the Dao do not follow its decay, do not trace its origin—this is where discussion stops."

Little Knowledge said: "Jì Zhēn’s 'non-action' and Jiēzǐ’s 'or causation'—which of these two doctrines accords with reality, which pervades principle?" Great Master Tiáo said: "The crowing of roosters and the barking of dogs are what people know; yet even the greatest wisdom cannot describe in words their spontaneous transformations, nor anticipate in thought what they will do. Analyzing this, the essence reaches the unparalleled, the greatness reaches the unbounded."

"‘Or causation’ and ‘non-action’—both avoid entanglement with things yet are ultimately deemed erroneous. ‘Or causation’ is substantive, ‘non-action’ is vacuous. Having name and reality is where things reside; lacking name and reality lies in the void of things. What can be spoken or conceived only grows more so with words. The unborn cannot be shunned, death cannot be prevented. Life and death are not distant, yet their principle cannot be perceived. ‘Or causation’ and ‘non-action’—these are but borrowed terms for doubt.

I observe their root: its going is without end. I seek their end: its coming is without cease. Without end, without cease—words fail here, yet this is the same principle as things. ‘Or causation’ and ‘non-action’ are the root of this. They accompany things from beginning to end.

The Dao cannot be possessed, possession cannot be devoid of it. The Dao as a name is but a borrowed means to proceed. ‘Or causation’ and ‘non-action’ are but one corner of things—how could they suffice for the great square?

If words were sufficient, then speaking all day would exhaust the Dao. If words were insufficient, then speaking all day would only speak of things. The ultimate of Dao and things cannot be borne by speech or silence. Neither speech nor silence—discussion reaches its limit here."

Little Knowledge said: "Jì Zhēn’s 'non-action' and Jiēzǐ’s 'or causation'—which of these two doctrines accords with reality, which pervades principle?" Great Master Tiáo said: "The crowing of roosters and the barking of dogs are what people know; yet even the greatest wisdom cannot describe in words their spontaneous transformations, nor anticipate in thought what they will do. Analyzing this, the essence reaches the unparalleled, the greatness reaches the unbounded."

chunks.original_text: 外物不可必，故龙逢诛，比干戮，箕子狂，恶来死，桀、纣亡。 人主不欲其臣之忠，而忠未必信，故伍员流于江，苌弘死于蜀，藏其血三年而化为碧。 人亲不欲其子之孝，而孝未必爱，故孝己忧而曾参悲。 木与木相摩则然，金与火相守则，阴阳错行，则天地大骇，于是乎有雷霆，水中有火，乃焚大槐。 有甚忧两陷而无所逃。 螴蜳不得成，心若县于天地之间，慰暋沈屯，利害相摩，生火甚多，众人焚和，月固不胜火，于是乎有僓而道尽。 庄周家贫，故往贷粟于监河侯。 监河侯曰：「诺，我将得邑金，将贷子百金，可乎？ 」庄周忿然作色曰：「周昨来，有中道而呼者。 周顾视车辙中，有鲋鱼焉。 周问之曰：『鲋鱼来﹗子何为者耶？ 』对曰：『我，东海之波臣也。 岂有斗升之水而活我哉？ 』周曰：『诺，我且南游吴越之王，激西江之水而迎子，可乎？ 』鲋鱼忿然作色曰：『吾失我常与，我无所处。 我得斗升之水然活。 君乃言此，曾不如早索我于枯鱼之肆﹗』」 任公子为大钩巨缁，五十犗以为饵，蹲乎会稽，投竿东海，旦旦而钓，期年不得鱼。 已而大鱼食之，牵钩陷，没而下，骛扬而奋鬐，白波若山，海震荡，声侔鬼神，惮赫千里。 任公子得若鱼，离而腊之，自制河以东，苍梧已北，莫不厌若鱼者。 已而后世辁才说之徒，皆惊而相告也。 夫揭竿累，趣灌渎，守鲵鲋，其于得大鱼难矣，饰小说以干县令，其于大达亦远矣，是以未尝闻任氏之风俗，其不可与经于世亦远！ 儒以《诗》、《礼》发冢。 大儒胪传曰：「东方作矣，事之何若？ 」小儒：「未解裙襦，口中有珠。 」《诗》固有之曰：『青青之麦，生于陵陂。 生不布施，何含珠为？ 』接其鬓，压其顪，儒以金椎控其颐，徐别其颊，无伤口中珠﹗」 老莱子之弟子出薪，遇仲尼，反以告，曰：「有人于彼，修上而趋下，而后耳，视若营四海，不知其谁氏之子。 」老莱子曰：「是丘也，召而来。 」仲尼至。 曰：「丘，去汝躬矜与汝容知，斯为君子矣。 」仲尼揖而退，蹙然改容问曰：「业可得进乎？ 」老莱子曰：「夫不忍一世之伤而骜万世之患，抑固窭邪，亡其略弗及邪？ 惠以欢为骜，终身之丑，中民之行进焉耳，相引以名，相结以。 与其誉尧而非桀，不如两忘而闭其所誉。 反无非伤也。 动无非邪也。 圣人踌躇兴事，以每成功。 奈何哉其载焉终矜尔！ 」

External things cannot be relied upon—thus Longfeng was executed, Bigan was slain, Jizi feigned madness, Elai met his death, and Jie and Zhou perished. A ruler does not desire his ministers’ loyalty, yet loyalty does not necessarily earn trust; thus Wu Yun was cast into the river, Chang Hong died in Shu, and his blood, stored for three years, turned to jade-green. A parent does not desire a child’s filial piety, yet filial piety does not necessarily bring love; thus Xiaoji grieved and Zeng Shen mourned.

When wood rubs against wood, it ignites; when metal is held to fire, it melts. When yin and yang clash in their courses, heaven and earth are thrown into great turmoil—then thunder and lightning arise, fire appears in water, and even the great locust tree is consumed. There is such sorrow when one is trapped between two perils with no escape.

The mantis cannot complete its strike, the heart hangs suspended between heaven and earth, comfort and distress intermingle, profit and harm grind against each other, and the fire of life burns fiercely. The multitude scorches harmony, and the moon is no match for fire—thus the Way is exhausted and collapses.

Zhuang Zhou was poor, so he went to borrow grain from the Marquis of the River. The marquis said, “Very well. When I receive the tax silver from my fief, I will lend you a hundred gold pieces—will that do?” Zhuang Zhou flushed with anger and said, “Yesterday, as I came, I heard a voice calling from the middle of the road. I looked and saw a crucian carp in the rut of a cart wheel. I asked it, ‘Crucian carp! What are you doing here?’ It replied, ‘I am a wave-minister of the Eastern Sea. Could you spare a dipper or two of water to keep me alive?’ I said, ‘Very well. I am about to travel south to persuade the kings of Wu and Yue, and I will divert the waters of the Western River to bring you home—will that do?’ The crucian carp flushed with anger and said, ‘I have lost my usual element, I have nowhere to go. I could be kept alive with a dipper or two of water. Yet you speak like this—you might as well have looked for me sooner in a dried-fish shop!’”

Lord Ren made a great hook with a thick black line, baited it with fifty steers, crouched on Mount Kuaiji, and cast his rod into the Eastern Sea. He fished day after day for a year without catching anything. Then a great fish took the bait, dragged the hook down, and plunged into the depths, thrashing its fins and churning white waves like mountains. The sea trembled, its roar matching the gods, and its dreadful power spread for a thousand miles. Lord Ren caught the fish, butchered it, and dried it. From the east of the Yellow River to the north of Cangwu, there was no one who did not feast on it.

Yet later, the petty and clever talkers all marveled and spread the tale. Those who raise a flimsy rod, rush to irrigation ditches, and watch for minnows and crucian carp—how could they ever catch a great fish? Those who embellish trivial words to seek high office—how far are they from great understanding? Thus, those who have never heard of the customs of the Ren clan are far indeed from being able to navigate the world.

Confucians use the *Odes* and *Rites* to rob graves. A great Confucian intoned, “The east is stirring—how goes the affair?” A lesser Confucian replied, “The skirt and jacket are not yet removed, but there is a pearl in the mouth.” The *Odes* indeed say: *“The green-green wheat grows on the hillside. If one does not give in life, why hold a pearl in death?”* They seized the hair, pressed the chin, and with a metal mallet, struck the jaw to pry open the cheeks—all without harming the pearl in the mouth!

A disciple of Lao Laizi was gathering firewood when he encountered Confucius. He returned and reported, “There is someone over there—tall above, hastening below, with ears set back, gazing as if surveying the four seas. I do not know whose son he is.” Lao Laizi said, “That is Qiu. Summon him.” Confucius arrived, and Lao Laizi said, “Qiu, rid yourself of your bodily pride and your cultivated knowledge—then you may become a gentleman.” Confucius bowed and withdrew, his expression troubled. He asked, “May I advance in my work?” Lao Laizi said, “To be unable to bear the harm of one age and yet rush headlong into the calamities of ten thousand ages—is this not stubborn and narrow? Or is it that your plans fall short? Kindness that takes delight in recklessness is a lifelong disgrace. The conduct of the common people advances thus, drawing one another by reputation, binding one another with... Better to forget both Yao’s praise and Jie’s blame, and close off the very source of praise. To turn back is not to be free of harm; to act is not to be free of error. The sage hesitates to initiate affairs, yet each one succeeds. Why then do you persist in bearing your pride to the end?”

*(End of Scroll 9, Part 26: External Things)*

chunks.original_text: 宋元君夜半而梦人被发窥阿门，曰：「予自宰路之渊，予为清江使河伯所，渔者余且得予。 」元君觉，使人占之，曰：「此神龟也。 」君曰：「渔者有余且乎？ 」左右曰：「有。 」君曰：「令余且会朝。 」明日，余且朝。 君曰：「渔得？ 」对曰：「且之网得白龟焉，箕圆五尺。 」君曰：「献若之龟。 」龟至，君再欲杀之，再欲活之，心疑，卜之，曰：「杀龟以卜吉。 」乃刳龟，七十二钻无遗策。 仲尼曰：「神龟能见梦于元君，而不能避余且之网； 知能七十二钻而无遗策，不能避刳肠之患。 如是，则知有所困，神有所不及也。 虽有至知，万谋之。 鱼不畏网而畏鹈鹕。 去小知而大知明，去善而自善矣。 婴儿生无石师而能言，与能言者处也。 」 惠子谓庄子曰：「子言无用。 」庄子曰：「知无用而始可与言用矣。 天非不广且大也，人之所用容足耳，然则厕足而垫之致黄泉，人尚有用乎？ 」惠子曰：「无。 」庄子曰：「然则无用之为用也亦明矣。 」 庄子曰：「人有能游，且得不游乎？ 人而不能游，且得游乎？ 夫流遁之，决绝之，噫，其非至知厚德之任与！ 覆坠而不反，火驰而不顾。 虽相与为君臣，时也，易而无以相贱。 故曰：至人不留行焉。 夫尊古而卑今，学者之流也。 且以狶韦氏之流观今之世，夫孰能不波，唯至人乃能游于世而不僻，顺人而不失己。 彼教学，承意不彼。 目彻为明，耳彻为聪，鼻彻为颤，口彻为甘，心彻为知，知彻为德。 道不欲壅，壅则哽，哽而不止则跈，跈则众害生。 物之有知者恃息，其不殷，非天之罪。 天之穿之，日夜无降，人则顾塞其窦。 胞有重阆，心有天游，室无虚，则妇姑勃溪； 心无天游，则六凿相攘。 大林丘山之善于人也，亦神者不胜。 德溢乎名，名溢乎暴，谋稽乎誸，知出乎争，柴生乎守官，事果乎众宜。 春雨时，草木怒生，铫耨于是乎始修，草木之倒植者过半而不知其然。 静默可以补病，眦搣可以休老，宁可以止遽。 虽然，若是，劳者之务，佚者之所未尝过而问焉。 圣人之所以駴天下，神人未尝过而问焉； 贤人所以駴世，圣人未尝过而问焉； 君子所以駴国，贤人未尝过而问焉； 小人所以合时，子未尝过而问焉。 演门有亲死者，以善毁爵为官师，其党人毁而死者半。 尧与许由天下，许由逃之； 汤与务光，务光怒之； 纪他闻之，帅弟子而踆于窾水，侯吊之。 三年，申徒狄因以踣河。 荃者所以在鱼，得鱼而忘荃； 蹄者所以在兔，得兔而忘蹄； 言者所以意，得意而忘言。 吾安得夫忘言之人而与之言哉！ 」 卷九上第二十七寓言

Duke Yuan of Song dreamed in the dead of night of a man with disheveled hair peering through the side gate. The man said, “I come from the abyss of Zailu. I was sent by the Clear River as an emissary to the River Lord, but the fisherman Yu Ju caught me.” The Duke awoke and had the dream interpreted. The diviner said, “This is a spirit turtle.” The Duke asked, “Is there a fisherman named Yu Ju?” His attendants replied, “There is.” The Duke said, “Summon Yu Ju to court.”

The next day, Yu Ju appeared. The Duke asked, “What did you catch?” Yu Ju answered, “I cast my net and caught a white turtle, five feet in circumference.” The Duke said, “Present your turtle.” When the turtle arrived, the Duke wavered—once wanting to kill it, once wanting to spare it. His mind unsettled, he consulted the oracle, which said, “Killing the turtle for divination will bring good fortune.” So they carved the turtle open, and in seventy-two drillings, not a single prediction failed.

Confucius said, “The spirit turtle could appear in the Duke’s dream yet could not escape Yu Ju’s net. It could foresee seventy-two divinations without error yet could not avoid the calamity of having its entrails carved out. Thus, even knowledge has its limitations, and even the divine has its shortcomings. Though one may possess supreme wisdom, ten thousand schemes are needed. Fish do not fear nets but fear pelicans. Discard petty knowledge, and great knowledge becomes clear; abandon contrived goodness, and true goodness arises of itself. An infant, born without a teacher of stone, learns to speak by dwelling among those who can.”

Huizi said to Zhuangzi, “Your words are useless.” Zhuangzi replied, “Only when one understands uselessness can we speak of use. The heavens are neither narrow nor small, yet what man uses is no more than the space his feet occupy. If one were to dig beneath his feet to the Yellow Springs, would there still be use?” Huizi said, “No.” Zhuangzi said, “Then the usefulness of the useless is also clear.”

Zhuangzi said, “If a man has the ability to wander freely, can he choose not to? If a man lacks the ability, can he wander at all? To drift and flee, to cut off all ties—alas, is this not beyond the capacity of even the wisest and most virtuous? To fall and not turn back, to rush like fire and not look back—though they may be ruler and minister for a time, their relationship is transient, shifting without mutual contempt. Thus it is said: the perfected person does not linger in his actions. Those who exalt the past and belittle the present follow the current of scholars. Yet if we observe the present age through the lens of the age of the Divine Farmer, who can avoid being swept along? Only the perfected person can wander through the world without bias, following others without losing himself. Their teaching and learning do not impose upon one another.

Eyes that penetrate see clearly; ears that penetrate hear keenly; noses that penetrate smell acutely; mouths that penetrate taste sweetness; minds that penetrate know; knowledge that penetrates becomes virtue. The Dao does not wish to be obstructed—obstruction leads to choking, and if choking persists, it becomes stumbling, from which a multitude of harms arise. Beings with knowledge rely on breath; if it does not flow smoothly, it is not heaven’s fault. Heaven pierces them day and night without ceasing, yet man clogs his own apertures.

The womb has its layered chambers; the mind has its heavenly wanderings. If the room is never empty, mother and daughter-in-law will quarrel; if the mind has no heavenly wandering, the six senses will jostle one another. The great forests and mountains are good for man, yet even the spiritually endowed cannot fully master them.

Virtue overflows into fame, fame overflows into violence, schemes stagnate in cunning, knowledge emerges from strife, barriers arise from clinging to office, and affairs are settled by what suits the crowd. When spring rains fall in season, grasses and trees flourish, and the hoe and plow begin their work. Yet more than half of the plants grow upside down, unaware of their own inversion.

Stillness and silence can heal illness; rubbing the corners of the eyes can rejuvenate the old; tranquility can halt haste. Yet even so, those who toil never inquire of those at leisure. The sage’s way of startling the world is something the spiritually realized never inquire about; the worthy’s way of startling the age is something the sage never inquires about; the noble’s way of startling the state is something the worthy never inquire about; the petty man’s way of conforming to the times is something the noble never inquires about.

In Yanmen, there was a man whose parent died. Because he mourned so well, he was appointed an official tutor. Half of his fellow villagers followed his example and mourned themselves to death. Yao offered the world to Xu You, but Xu You fled; Tang offered it to Wu Guang, but Wu Guang grew angry; Ji Ta heard of this and led his disciples to crouch by the Kuang River, awaiting condolences. Three years later, Shentu Di drowned himself in the Yellow River.

The fish trap exists for the sake of catching fish; once the fish is caught, the trap is forgotten. The rabbit snare exists for the sake of catching rabbits; once the rabbit is caught, the snare is forgotten. Words exist for the sake of meaning; once the meaning is grasped, the words are forgotten. Where can I find a man who has forgotten words, that I might speak with him?”

chunks.original_text: 寓言十九，重言十七，卮言日出，和以天倪。 寓言十九，藉外论之。 亲父不为其子媒。 亲父誉之，不若非其父者也； 非罪也，人之罪也。 与己同则应，不与己同则反； 同于己为是之，异于己为非之。 重言十七，所以己言也。 是为耆艾，年先矣，而无经纬本末以期年耆者，是非也。 人而无以先人，无人道也； 人而无人道，是之谓陈人。 卮言日出，和以天倪，因以曼衍，所以穷年。 不言则齐，齐与言不齐，言与齐不齐也。 故曰：「无。 」言无言，终身言，未尝不言； 终身不言，未尝不言。 有自也而可，有自也而不； 有自也而然，有自也而不然。

Nineteen in ten of words are parables; seventeen in ten are reiterations; goblet words emerge daily, harmonized by the Heavenly Equilibrium.

Nineteen in ten of words are parables, relying on external voices to expound. A loving father does not act as matchmaker for his son. If a father praises his own son, it is not as credible as if a non-father did so. This is no fault of his own—it is the fault of others. When others align with oneself, one responds; when they do not align, one resists. What aligns with oneself is deemed right; what differs is deemed wrong.

Seventeen in ten are reiterations, used to affirm one’s own words. These are the words of elders, those whose years precede ours. Yet if they lack the warp and weft of fundamental principles to guide those who follow, they are in error. A person who cannot surpass others lacks the human Way; one who lacks the human Way is called a withered remnant.

Goblet words emerge daily, harmonized by the Heavenly Equilibrium, flowing and unfolding to exhaust the years. Without words, all is equal; equality with words is not equality, and words with equality are not equality. Thus it is said: "Nothing." Words without words—throughout a lifetime, one speaks, yet never truly speaks; throughout a lifetime, one does not speak, yet never truly ceases to speak. There is that by which something is permissible, and that by which it is not; there is that by which something is so, and that by which it is not so.

Whence comes "so"? It is so in being so. Whence comes "not so"? It is not so in being not so. Whence comes "permissible"? It is permissible in being permissible. Whence comes "impermissible"? It is impermissible in being impermissible. Things inherently have that by which they are so; things inherently have that by which they are permissible. Yet there is nothing that is not so, nothing that is not permissible.

Without goblet words emerging daily, harmonized by the Heavenly Equilibrium, who could endure for long? All things are seeds, succeeding one another through differing forms, beginning and end like a ring, attaining their proper order—this is called the Heavenly Equilibrium. The Heavenly Equilibrium is the Heavenly Equilibrium.

Zhuangzi said to Huizi: "Confucius lived sixty years, and in sixty years he transformed. What he initially affirmed, he ultimately negated. Who knows whether what he called 'right' at sixty was not the 'wrong' of fifty-nine?" Huizi replied: "Confucius diligently applied his will and employed his knowledge." Zhuangzi said: "Confucius has renounced such things; he never spoke of them. Confucius said: 'One receives one’s endowment from the great root and restores the numinous to life. To sing in accord with the pitch-pipes, to speak in accord with the laws—profit and righteousness arrayed before one, yet likes and dislikes, right and wrong merely subdue men’s mouths. Master Zeng took office twice, and his heart transformed twice. He said: "When I first served while my parents were alive, a stipend of three *fu* brought joy to my heart; later, when I served after their passing, three thousand *zhong* could not reach them, and my heart grieved." A disciple asked Confucius: "Can one say that Shen here is free of blame?" Confucius replied: "He is already blameworthy! How could one free of blame feel such sorrow? To him, three *fu* or three thousand *zhong* were like watching sparrows, mosquitoes, or gadflies pass before him."

Yan Chengzi You said to Dongguo Ziqi: "Since I heard your words, in one year I became rustic; in two, I followed; in three, I penetrated; in four, I became one with things; in five, they came to me; in six, spirits entered; in seven, Heaven was accomplished; in eight, I knew neither death nor life; in nine, I attained the great mystery. Life is active; death is loss. You hold that death has its source, while life—yang as it is—has none. Is this truly so? Where does it go? Where does it not go? Heaven has its celestial reckoning, earth has its human foundations—where should I seek them? If none knows its end, how can one say there is no fate? If none knows its beginning, how can one say there is fate? When there is resonance, how can one say there are no spirits? When there is no resonance, how can one say there are spirits?"

The shadowy wraiths asked the shadow: "Earlier you bowed your head, now you raise it; earlier your hair was bound, now it is loose; earlier you sat, now you stand; earlier you walked, now you halt—why?" The shadow replied: "Such trifling matters—why ask at all? I act, yet know not why. I am like the cicada’s molted husk, the snake’s sloughed skin—resembling them yet not them. Fire and sunlight are my gathering; darkness and night are my succession. Do I depend on these? How much more so those who depend on what depends! When it comes, I come with it; when it goes, I go with it; when it is strong and yang, I am strong and yang with it. What question is there in strong yang?"

Yang Ziju journeyed south to Pei, while Lao Dan traveled west to Qin. They met on the outskirts of Liang, where Laozi sighed to the sky mid-journey: "At first I thought you could be taught, but now you cannot." Yang Ziju made no reply. Upon reaching their lodging, he presented water for washing, a towel and comb, removed his shoes outside the door, and advanced on his knees, saying: "Earlier, your disciple wished to ask you a question, but you were too occupied to pause—so I dared not. Now, may I inquire the reason?" Laozi said: "Your haughty gaze, your overbearing mien—who would dwell with you? The purest white seems tarnished; the greatest virtue seems insufficient." Yang Ziju’s expression changed abruptly, and he said: "I humbly receive your instruction."

When he had first arrived, the innkeeper had welcomed him with deference, the master of the house had laid out his mat, the wife had held his towel, the guests had yielded their seats, and those tending the stove had stepped aside. Upon his return, the innkeeper contended with him for his seat.

Chapter Twenty-Eight: Yielding the Throne

Yao offered the empire to Xu You, who declined. He then offered it to Zizhou Zhipu, who said: "If you deem me fit, it would be acceptable. Yet I happen to suffer from a deep melancholy, and am just now treating it—I have no leisure to govern the empire." The empire is the weightiest of burdens, yet he would not let it harm his life—how much less other things! Only one who takes no account of the empire can be entrusted with it.

Shun offered the empire to Zizhou Bo, who said: "I happen to suffer from a deep melancholy, and am just now treating it—I have no leisure for the empire." Thus the empire is a great vessel, yet one does not exchange life for it. This is how those who possess the Way differ from the common.

Shun offered the empire to Shan Juan, who said: "I stand amid the cosmos: in winter I wear furs, in summer I wear hemp; in spring I plow and sow, and my strength suffices for labor; in autumn I reap and gather, and my body suffices for rest and sustenance."

chunks.translated_text:
With the sun’s rising, I rise to work; with the sun’s setting, I rest—roaming free between heaven and earth, my heart content. Why should I take the empire for myself? Alas, how little you understand me!

Thus he refused it. Then he departed and entered the deep mountains, where he dwelled.

Shun offered the empire to his friend, the farmer of Stone Gate. The farmer of Stone Gate said: “How toilsome is the lord’s conduct! He exhausts his strength in service.” He deemed Shun’s virtue not yet perfected. Thereupon, he shouldered his goods, his wife carried their belongings on her head, and they led their child into the sea, never to return.

King Tai of Danfu dwelled in Bin. The Di tribes attacked him. He offered them furs and silks, but they refused; he offered them dogs and horses, but they refused; he offered them pearls and jades, but they refused. What the Di sought was land. King Tai of Danfu said: “To dwell with a man’s elder brother and kill his younger brother, to dwell with a man’s father and kill his son—I cannot bear it. Go, all of you, and dwell as you will! What difference is there between serving me and serving the Di? Moreover, I have heard that one must not harm what nourishes for the sake of nourishment.” Thereupon, he took up his staff and departed. The people followed him in a continuous stream, and he established a state beneath Mount Qi.

King Tai of Danfu was one who honored life. Those who honor life, though noble and wealthy, do not let nourishment harm the body; though poor and lowly, do not let profit burden the form. Nowadays, those who occupy high office all fear losing it. Seeing profit, they lightly cast aside their lives—how deluded they are!

The people of Yue murdered their ruler for three generations. Prince Sou, distressed by this, fled into the cinnabar caves. When Yue was left without a ruler, they sought Prince Sou, following him to the cinnabar caves. Prince Sou refused to emerge, so the people of Yue smoked him out with mugwort. They bore him away in the royal carriage. Prince Sou grasped the reins and mounted the chariot, gazing up to heaven and crying: “Lordship! Lordship! Can you not spare me this?” Prince Sou did not hate being lord; he hated the calamity of being lord. Such was Prince Sou—one who would not let the state harm his life. This was precisely what the people of Yue desired in a lord.

Han and Wei contended over encroached land. Master Hua Zi visited Marquis Zhao of Han, who wore a troubled expression. Master Hua Zi said: “Suppose the world inscribed a pledge before you, saying: ‘If you seize it with your left hand, your right hand will be lost; if you seize it with your right hand, your left hand will be lost. Yet whoever seizes it will gain the world.’ Would you seize it?” Marquis Zhao said: “I would not.” Master Hua Zi said: “Excellent! From this we see that your two arms are weightier than the world, and your body is weightier than your two arms. Han’s standing in the world is far lighter than this, and what you now contend over is even lighter still. Yet you grieve and harm your life over what you cannot obtain!” Marquis Zhao said: “Well said! Many have instructed me, but never have I heard this.” Master Hua Zi had made him understand the weight of things.

The Lord of Lu heard that Yan He was a man who had attained the Way, and sent an envoy bearing gifts to precede him. Yan He dwelled in a humble lane, wearing coarse hempen clothes and herding oxen himself. When the Lord of Lu’s envoy arrived, Yan He received him in person. The envoy said: “Is this Yan He’s home?” Yan He replied: “This is He’s home.” The envoy presented the gifts, but Yan He said: “I fear a misunderstanding may bring blame upon the envoy—it would be better to verify.” The envoy returned to confirm, then came back to seek him, but Yan He could no longer be found.

Thus, one like Yan He truly despised wealth and honor. Therefore it is said: The true essence of the Way is for governing the self; its remnants may be used for the state; its dregs for governing the world. From this we see that the achievements of kings are but the leavings of sages, not what perfects the self or nourishes life. Yet today’s worldly gentlemen often endanger their bodies and abandon their lives to pursue things—how lamentable!

Whenever sages act, they must examine their motives and their aims. Suppose there were a man here who, to shoot a bird a thousand yards away, used the Pearl of Marquis Sui—all would surely laugh at him. Why? Because what he valued was heavy, and what he sought was light. Life—is it not far weightier than the Pearl of Marquis Sui?

Master Lie was poor, and his countenance bore the hue of hunger. A guest mentioned this to Zi Yang of Zheng, saying: “Lie Yukou is a scholar of the Way, yet he dwells in this state in poverty. Does my lord not love scholars?” Zi Yang of Zheng immediately ordered an official to send him grain. When Master Lie saw the envoy, he bowed twice and declined. The envoy departed, and Master Lie entered his home. His wife, striking her breast, said: “I have heard that the wife of one who possesses the Way lives in ease and joy. Yet you bear the hue of hunger. The lord sent you food, but you refused it—is this not fate?” Master Lie laughed and said to her: “The lord does not know me. He sent me grain on another’s word, and if he were to punish me, it would also be on another’s word. This is why I did not accept.” Later, the people indeed rebelled and killed Zi Yang.

King Zhao of Chu lost his state, and the butcher Yue followed him in exile. When King Zhao returned to his state, he wished to reward those who had followed him, including the butcher Yue. Yue said: “When the great king lost his state, I lost my butchery; when the great king returned, I returned to my butchery. My rank and emolument are restored—what reward is there?” The king said: “Insist!” The butcher Yue said: “When the great king lost his state, it was not my fault, so I dared not accept punishment; when the great king returned, it was not my merit, so I dared not claim reward.” The king said: “Let me see him.”

The butcher Yue said: “According to the laws of Chu, only those with great merit may be granted an audience. Now, my wisdom was not sufficient to preserve the state, nor was my courage sufficient to die resisting the enemy. When the Wu army entered Ying, I fled from danger and did not follow the great king by design. If the great king now wishes to set aside the law and violate precedent to receive me, this is not what I wish to be heard throughout the world.” The king said to Marshal Zi Qi: “Though the butcher Yue’s station is lowly, his principles are lofty. Zi Qi, offer him a position with the three standards of rank.” The butcher Yue said: “The position with three standards—I know it is nobler than my butcher’s stall; the salary of ten thousand bushels—I know it is richer than my butcher’s profit. Yet how could I covet rank and emolument and thereby cause my lord to gain a reputation for reckless bestowal? I dare not accept. I wish only to return to my butcher’s stall.” Thus he declined.

Yuan Xian lived in Lu in a walled hut with a roof of thatch; the gate was made of tangled brambles, incomplete; the door pivot was of mulberry wood; two earthen jars served as windows, sealed with reeds. Above, the roof leaked; below, the floor was damp. Yet he sat upright and played the zither. Zigong arrived in a grand carriage, his inner robe dark blue and his outer robe white, the axle of his high chariot too wide to pass through the lane. He went to see Yuan Xian. Yuan Xian, wearing a hat of woven rushes and shoes with untied laces, leaned on a staff of bramble and answered the door. Zigong said: “Alas! Master, what afflicts you?” Yuan Xian replied: “I have heard that to be poor without complaint is not poverty, but to study without putting it into practice is affliction. Now I am poor, not afflicted.” Zigong retreated, his face flushed with shame. Yuan Xian said: “To act for the sake of fame, to befriend for the sake of cliques, to study for others, to teach for oneself, to conceal one’s virtue with benevolence and righteousness, to adorn oneself with carriages and horses—these are things I cannot bear to do.”

Zengzi lived in Wei, his padded robe unlined, his complexion swollen and sallow, his hands and feet calloused. For three days he did not light a fire, for ten years he did not make new clothes. When he put on his cap, the ties snapped; when he grasped his lapel, his elbows showed; when he pulled on his shoes, the heels split. Yet he dragged his hem and sang the *Odes of Shang*, his voice filling heaven and earth, resonant as metal and stone. The Son of Heaven could not make him a subject, nor could the feudal lords make him a friend. Thus, those who cultivate the will forget the body; those who cultivate the body forget profit; those who attain the Dao forget the mind.

Confucius said to Yan Hui: “Hui, come! Your family is poor and your station low—why do you not enter official service?” Yan Hui replied: “I do not wish to serve. Outside the outer wall, I have fifty *mu* of fields, enough to provide gruel and porridge; within the outer wall, I have ten *mu* of fields, enough to provide silk and hemp. Playing the zither is enough to amuse myself; what I have learned of the Master’s Dao is enough to bring me joy.”

When Tang was about to attack Jie, he consulted Bian Sui, who said: "This is not my affair." Tang asked: "Who then is suitable?" Bian Sui replied: "I do not know." Tang then consulted Mao Guang, who said: "This is not my affair." Tang asked: "Who then is suitable?" Mao Guang replied: "I know." Tang said: "What of Yi Yin?" Mao Guang answered: "He is strong and enduring, patient of disgrace—I know nothing else of him." Thereupon Tang conspired with Yi Yin to attack Jie, defeated him, and offered the throne to Bian Sui. Bian Sui declined, saying: "When the ruler plotted against Jie, he consulted me—he must have thought me a villain. Now that he has defeated Jie and offers me the throne, he must think me greedy.
